PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of the Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
1. PVR will inhibit the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Was any good purpose achieved by Australia's abstention from the United Nations vote seeking further negotiations on the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands? Would not Australia have realised the embarrassment that this decision would be to Margaret Thatcher and to Britain? Was determination to be independent at any cost, or desire to please America, an influence in the decision to abstain from voting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has been in close communication with the United Kingdom throughout the dispute, including in relation to the deficiencies of the Argentine resolution. Australia did not vote against the resolution because of the positive elements it contained in emphasising a peaceful settlement through negotiation, according a measure of recognition to the interests of the Falklanders and building on previous United Nations mediation efforts. Our well-known views on the rights of the islanders and on the facts of the Argentine invasion were again made clear. In these important matters Australia spoke in support of Britain. The British Government has expressed appreciation for the fact that Australia at an early stage had made known its intention to abstain on the Falklands resolution.

—My question is addressed to Senator Peter Baume in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs or alternatively as Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that a recent evaluation by the Commonwealth Government of its spending on Aboriginal health supported the view that funding to the States has not achieved the Government's purpose because the States as a whole have not accepted the Commonwealth policy of involving Aboriginals in the design, control and delivery of health services for Aboriginals and the States have used the savings for services that the States should pay for themselves as part of their own responsibility for the health of all residents? Will the Government make the evaluation available to the Senate? Do the statistics also show that such health funds are unevenly distributed among the States, with Western Australia, with 16 per cent of the Aboriginal population, receiving about 50 per cent of these funds but still failing to attract Aboriginal support for its programs? In these circumstances, what action will the Commonwealth take to secure a more effective program and, in particular, more control by Aboriginals in the design and delivery of such services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs several reviews of Aboriginal health had occurred, some of them public, in which there had been criticism of the activities of some of the States in providing for Aboriginal health using funds from the Commonwealth under State grants provisions. There has been considerable movement and change since that time. The State grants for Aboriginal health provide a base for a large amount of Aboriginal employment. There are a large number of Aboriginal health workers whose funding is dependent upon some State grants continuing. It is correct to say, though, that there was criticism. As a result of that criticism the Commonwealth, in the last two years, has opened up negotiations with the various States and the Northern Territory with a view to changing the arrangements and to involving Aboriginals to a greater extent in the design, planning, implementation and evaluation of health services for themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time, the Commonwealth has funded a large number of Aboriginal medical services controlled by Aboriginal people. During my time as Minister we extended the number of independent Aboriginal medical services which were funded and which operate now as independent Aboriginal-controlled organisations. But it would be wrong to suggest that the States have been non-responsive. Senator Missen represents Victoria. He would be interested to know that the previous Victorian State Government and the Commonwealth were able to negotiate at the end of last year a new arrangement for the use of State grants moneys and for the provision of health services in Victoria. As a result of those arrangements an entirely new system of health services was implemented in Victoria, which was Aboriginal controlled. Victoria agreed to give up much of the money which it had been receiving. The Commonwealth reallocated that money to Aboriginal medical services.

The point I want to make is that the criticisms which were made in the last two or three years were significant but they have been followed up by action by the Commonwealth and by States to improve the situation. Some of the States other than Victoria, for example, have created new advisory committees and new positions for Aboriginals to help to direct what occurs in that State in terms of the way its medical services are delivered. I will have to ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether the situation is yet satisfactory. I do know that there has been progress. I will refer Senator Missen's question to the Minister whom I represent in case there is something that can be added.

The final point I make concerns Senator Missen's question about the percentage of Aboriginal population and the percentage of money applied State by State. When the program was introduced some States got going more quickly than other States. Those States that were up and running first seem to have the largest programs in operation. I think that over the last few years there has been an attempt to alter the percentages slightly to bring them back towards the population ratio. We will have to look at the result of the recent census to see the extent to which they are out of plumb. There is an historical reason which explains why some of the States get what appears to be an inordinately large amount of the money.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether his attention has been drawn to a speech made last week at a 'Save the Murray' campaign meeting in Adelaide by the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: When governments in this country can entertain the idea of finding massive amounts of money for something as transient as an Olympic Games-and when Australians themselves can find millions of dollars to bet on one horse race, however important-then I find it hard to believe that we cannot as a nation find money, over a period of years, for works such as water projects, which are of permanent and increasing value and importance.

Does that statement by the Acting Prime Minister indicate a new attitude with respect to Government policy dealing with the River Murray and other water projects? Will the Government give a higher priority and make more money available for their solution? If so, is the Government prepared to implement the former South Australian Government's proposal to find a permanent solution to the problems of the River Murray, which is estimated to cost about $400m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw something of a reported statement of the Acting Prime Minister. I think all Australians will agree with him that, if we are to look for priorities, water, which is our scarcest resource, ought to be given increasing priority. That is precisely what is happening under the Government's policies. For example, in the Budget appropriation that has been before the Senate, about $41.7m has been allocated to the National Water Resources Program, which is an increase of 28 per cent over the allocation for last year. It will be spread over the various States. In addition, there is the funding of the Burdekin Dam in Queensland, which is a major project.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jessop referred to the River Murray. He will know that the River Murray Waters Agreement has now been signed, that legislation has been introduced into another place to confirm that agreement and that the great qualitative undertakings for the control of the River Murray are now in process. The former State Government in South Australia came forward with a proposal which, taken in total over a number of years, would cost about $400m. The Government took the view that priorities could be achieved but not in the quantitative sense. Many had been represented by the Maunsell committee and the Government is proceeding to deal with them. Many are already in process. A working party has produced a report regarding the control of salinity, particularly in regard to irrigation processes along the River Murray. That report is being studied. The upgrading of attention to the River Murray is very real and very significant. I think that is acknowledged by the three States concerned. The work that we are now putting in hand on that alone will enhance the quality and quantity of flow of the water. But apart from that, the formation of a National Water Resources Council and the perspective overview study of water up to the year 2000 indicate the priorities that this Government is giving to water.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Following the Australian Labor Party's victory in South Australia on the ground that it changed its policy and supported the development of Roxby Downs, and given the failure of the Australian Democrat candidates in both Houses, is this not a South Australian endorsement of uranium mining and of the development of Roxby Downs in South Australia?
—You should not give information. He did not know that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button said that I did not know. I was asked a question by Senator Chipp as to public opinion about uranium mining. I reminded Senator Chipp that the only public opinion polls on it were those that had been taken by various reputable authorities and that they had shown a majority support for uranium mining as well as a majority support by supporters of the Australian Democrats for uranium mining. It is true that Senator Chipp's question was fundamentally wrong on the basis that, however belatedly, the Labor Party in South Australia changed its policies and said that it supported Roxby Downs. —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. As the United States Government has an often stated policy of neither confirming nor denying the existence of nuclear weapons on United States military vehicles, how is Mr Sinclair able to state, as Minister for Defence, that United States B52 aircraft are not carrying nuclear weapons while on flights over Australia?

—A number of questions in this connection have been raised from time to time by Senator Coleman and others. She knows that there is a genuine arrangement between the ANZUS partners-the United States of America and Australia-concerning B52 flights over Australia for training purposes only and not for the carriage of nuclear weapons. The assurances that can be gained from that arrangement are a clear matter of understanding between two sovereign nations. That is the situation. I would be only too pleased to refer to the Minister any particular allegation that the honourable senator might care to make.

—Does the Minister for Social Security remember the considerable controversy over an information insert in cheque mailings to Victorian pensioners earlier this year? Is he aware that unemployment beneficiaries in Victoria recently again received information inserts in cheque mailings? Would the Minister advise the Senate on what basis decisions are made to place information inserts into cheque mailings of social security payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the controversy referred to by the honourable senator. It related to the fact that arrangements had been made between the previous Victorian Government and my Department in Victoria to include with pensioners' cheques an insertion which advised on the availability of a booklet which detailed the concessions for pensioners which were available in that State. That was a matter which became controversial because, coincidentally, the inserts became closely related in time to the holding of the Victorian election. About half were sent prior to the election and about half after the election. As I indicated at that time, that was certainly fortuitous and the whole matter had been arranged departmentally and without reference to me.

ANSWER.PARA: Recently, the Department again without reference to me-I have no complaint about that-approved the inclusion with the cheques which are sent to unemployment beneficiaries in Victoria of an insert which advises them of some new concessions which have been offered by the present Victorian Government with respect to transport. The Victorian Government has made available a transport concession which will facilitate travel for the unemployed while they are on unemployment benefit. The notice advises them of the availability of a concession card which is valid for daily tickets. It is not available for travel in the metropolitan area before 9 a.m. Monday to Friday and so on. It is, consistent with the approach which is generally taken, a facility which is made available when it is thought to be in the interests of pensioners or beneficiaries.

As I indicated, guidelines have been laid down to govern the use of cheque inserts. Those guidelines cover the sorts of things that I think honourable senators would expect. For a start, there is a requirement that the insert should not give rise to any likelihood that there will be a delay in the dispatch of cheques. Of course, it is a primary responsibility of my Department to get payments out on time. We will provide inserts only for government departments or statutory authorities. We have to be able to make the judgment that the publicity is inoffensive to all groups within the client population, that it would not serve, even indirectly, commercial ends, that the inclusion could not be construed as an invasion of privacy and so on. In fact, a detailed set of rules applies in these cases.

Within the last week or two a cheque insert has been included with pensioners' cheques advising them of recent changes to the social security legislation. This is one valuable means which is available to the Government of informing the client population of my Department of information which is of assistance to them . I am pleased that Senator Hamer asked his question, because it was of concern to me that officers of my Department in Victoria were being subjected to the allegation that there had been some political bias on their part when I am quite satisfied that that was not the case. The rules are established. They are administered directly by officers of my Department, often without reference to me because the matter would not be one which required a policy decision if it were within the guidelines. I regard cheque inserts as a valuable means of getting information to our client population.

In view of the result of the referendum in South Australia relating to daylight saving, in which about three times as many people said that they wanted daylight saving as said that they did not want it, will the Minister ask the Minister for the Capital Territory to take the lead in the mainland areas and extend the period of daylight saving to six months in future summers and, at the end of the current period of daylight saving, extend the period for at least one month-something which I believe would have the overwhelming support of the people who have daylight saving?

—Senator Townley is right in drawing our attention to the result of the referendum in South Australia at the weekend, which demonstrated that, I think, nearly 80 per cent of the population support daylight saving in that State. As to the influence of the Minister for the Capital Territory in respect of all States of the Commonwealth, I would have doubts about that matter. Nevertheless, I will draw it to his attention and see whether he will confer with his relevant colleagues in the various States. As to the general thrust of the question and particularly the increase in the period that Senator Townley draws to our attention, it is, I think, a matter which would have different application in different States, as indeed we find in South Australia that daylight saving has different application in different parts of the State because of its breadth.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: SURPLUS OF DAIRY PRODUCTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In an effort to cut the United States of America dairy price support program, the United States Department of Agriculture Secretary, John Block, has proposed emergency legislation which will give the authority to cut United States milk support prices and reduce government-owned surpluses. These surpluses of butter have risen 61 per cent in the past 12 months. Cheese stocks are at 630 million lb, having risen 144 per cent in the same time. I ask the Minister: Has the Government yet been told how the United States plans to dispose of these mountains of dairy produce and at what prices we might expect to see them offered on world markets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are very significant amounts of butter and cheese which appear to be surplus in the United States. The matter raised by Senator Archer is one which naturally is of concern to the dairy industry here and no doubt around the world. I have some information from the Department of Primary Industry on this matter. I am advised that the United States Government has taken a number of measures to deal with the problem of its surplus dairy production. The support price for milk has been frozen at the existing level of $US13.10 per cwt until October 1984. The Secretary of Agriculture has been authorised to impose on milk producers an assessment of 50c per cwt of milk produced from 1 December 1982 and a further assessment of 50c per cwt from 1 April 1983 if purchases of dairy products by the commodity credit corporations are estimated to exceed certain annual levels. There have also been extensive give-away programs to reduce the holdings and some special arrangements such as the sale to New Zealand of 110,000 tonnes of butter. In fact these measures have not altered the build-up of surplus dairy stocks in the United States and the United States Government is considering the disposal of surplus dairy products on the world market.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is monitoring the situation closely. It has voiced concern at the likely impact on the world market of any large scale disposal of United States dairy surpluses and will continue to urge the United States to adopt acceptable solutions to the problem. We have obtained an undertaking from the United States Government that we will be consulted before the United States embarks on any program of disposal of surplus dairy products on the world market .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce: Will the Government be prepared to refer urgently to the Industries Assistance Commission or the Temporary Assistance Authority the crisis in manufacturing industry which has occurred since the Budget, and particularly in recent weeks? Is the Minister aware that major components manufacturers in the truck components industry are among the many industries which have had to introduce a four-day week after previous retrenchments, with the next step being closure? In view of the rapid deterioration in manufacturing industry which has occurred, particularly in the past few weeks, will the Government consider introducing temporary import quotas on a broad range of goods as soon as the IAC report is received?

—The present situation of manufacturing industry is, of course, a matter of great concern to the Government. The reduction in employment which has recently occurred is similarly a matter of great concern. A key problem which, of course, is affecting Australian industry, as it is international industry, is the very significant reduction in world trade which has occurred over the last year or so. If all countries adopted the course suggested by the honourable senator in his question the problem would be exacerbated and no doubt many Australian export industries would find themselves severely disadvantaged. One has to be very careful, in taking action of any sort, to ensure that it does not have side effects which simply increase the problem. I do not believe that the honourable senator's suggestion that a general reference be made to the Industries Assistance Commission would receive widespread support, even in industry itself. However, I will refer the suggestion to the Minister for Industry and Commerce for his consideration. The second part of the question really flows from that suggestion because it envisages an IAC report being made and some consequent government action taking place. But, as I say, I suspect that the proposal would not be widely welcomed among manufacturers in Australia. In any event I will ask Mr Peacock to give it consideration and provide a more considered reply to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General to the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission of January 1980 which recommended the establishment, without delay, of an Australian sentencing council to produce guidelines for the charging, prosecution and sentencing of Federal offenders and to review, among other things, statutory penalties in relation to Federal offenders. I refer him further to the answer given by the Acting Attorney-General to a question on notice from Mr Jacobi a couple of weeks ago in which the Government indicated that there was no prospect of that sentencing council being created in the near future because, as the Acting Attorney-General said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . only a minority of Attorneys-General expressed support for the proposal.

—Is the Minister for Education aware of a number of statements in today's Sydney Morning Herald alleging that the present Federal Government's scheme for funding non-government schools contains significant anomalies which frustrate the general objectives of the scheme? Are these statements true? If so , what action does the Minister propose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald . I do not have it with me, but I have read it. It is interesting that the editorial was supportive of Commonwealth aid to non-government schools. This Government will continue to give aid to all non-government schools. It is here to stay. We believe that the debate which is arising in the state aid area is yesterday's debate and has no place today. The editorial, supportive as it was, contained a few inaccuracies. It might be worth setting those to rest. First of all, Catholic schools in Australia are better off in real terms today than they ever have been. They are not worse off, as the editorial might have been seen to be implying. I have taken out some figures. I do not know what honourable senators regard as significant, but if they look at student-teacher ratios they will see that in Catholic primary schools they have improved since 1971 from 31 pupils per teacher to 23 pupils per teacher. In secondary schools the figure has gone down from 22 pupils per teacher to 16 pupils per teacher during the same period.
—Are you going to have an early election?

—It is interesting that the moment we bring out facts the people opposite seem to find them unpleasant. During the same period government schools have continued to improve in Australia. Although Catholic schools have improved significantly over the last 10 years they are still trying to catch up with the enormous improvement that has taken place in the government schools, which is now well ahead of previous targets.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the amount of money spent per student. About $1,400 is now spent on each government primary school student. About $1,070 is spent on each Catholic primary school student. In those terms the government schools are better off. The same figures apply in relation to secondary schools. I have a table showing the student-teacher ratios and another table showing the recurrent expenditure per head in government schools and Catholic schools between the two dates. I seek leave to have the tables incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Increased resources have been applied and there are diminishing pupil-teacher ratios. During that period the Catholic schools have had to put in place an enormous change from religious to lay teachers, and this they have been able to do. They have now got to where government schools were, but government schools have been going ahead. The editorial made a couple of other points which I think require some comment. The editorial talked about income testing and said that income testing of non- government schools was desirable. The facts are that income testing of selected schools was introduced in 1982. For 1983 it is proposed that all non-government schools which are on the higher subsidy rates will be income tested. So the suggestion that has been made is one that this Government is implementing in order to ensure that schools receiving higher subsidies do put a proper percentage of their fee money into recurrent programs. That does not stop any schools that decide they want to charge low fees for social purposes, for widening access, from doing so but it does ensure that income testing will take place. To that extent we are already doing what the Sydney Morning Herald said was desirable.

ANSWER.PARA: The final point made in the editorial was that there should be accountability by non-government schools for moneys which they receive. I have no doubt that there should be public acountability by anyone who receives public moneys for any purpose. I have no difficulty with the concept that that accountability should extend to the school system. At the moment the Commonwealth Schools Commission is examining for me the questions relating to accountability, including the possibility of making information publicly available in relation to some of these financial matters. I do not think it is useful in the debate to confine questions of accountability to non-government schools. If we are going to talk about accountability it is something which should apply right across the school system. It may be time to ask that the government school systems expose themselves to the same kind of public accountability for the use of money. I come back to where I began. What was good about the editorial was that it supported Commonwealth support for non-government schools, which is a central part of our program. As honourable senators know, the Commonwealth Government has a basic grant for all non-government schools. We do not have in prospect the divisive and destructive program being proposed by the Australian Labor Party which will seek to take away from a number of students and parents the support which they presently enjoy.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Given the parlous state of the building industry, can the Minister advise what would be the effect on the building industry and home buyers if the building union's demand for a 36-hour working week were granted?

—There seems to be an extraordinary inability on the part of at least some people in the community to do what seems to me to be simple arithmetic. Clearly, a further reduction in working hours in this critically important industry must mean that the unit cost of labour will rise and that further difficulties will be created for those who would seek to build homes, or any other buildings. In this period of Australia's economy it is without doubt that raising labour costs significantly would be counter-productive. It is likely that it would reduce activity in a field in which we are doing everything we can to increase activity because activity is much lower than we would wish. Quite clearly the request currently being made is not in the public interest or indeed in the private interest. I doubt whether it is even in the interests of the union which is making it, because it is likely to lead to less employment rather than more employment in the building industry for members of that union. It seems to me to be shortsighted in the extreme and one can only hope that the union will see that and not persist with a claim which, as I said, is against both its interests and the interests of the community.

The Minister representing the Minister for Health gave comfort to Senator Missen; but I wish to question one particular area. The Minister for Health stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The lack of a uniform, national data collection system, to provide an accurate measure of Aboriginal health status, is a deficiency which cannot be allowed to continue.

At the end of that statement he said that such a system was absolutely essential for monitoring and evaluating the effectiveness of health programs directed towards Aborigines. What steps has the Department of Health taken to implement this priority decision? Specifically, what staff have been allocated to the task , what are their qualifications and what financial resources have been committed to this priority? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Georges's question relates to one of the deficiencies outlined in the Minister's statement-that related specifically to the collection of data and statistics. I am working from memory, but I believe that at that stage we drew attention publicly to the proposals by a Dr L. Smith for a system of data collection. It was indicated then that we wished to try to pursue and support a proposal like the one which he put forward to try to gather statistics related to Aboriginal health. I would like to endorse what Senator Georges has said; that is, that the collection of adequate statistics is important in achieving the outcomes that we are seeking. I can indicate that following the tabling of that report a working party was established and negotiations were opened up with the States. The fact is that much of the data collection has to be carried out by the States.
—What has the Department of Health done?

—I will have to find out for Senator Georges where the matter rests at this stage because when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-we kept a watching brief together with the Department of Health in a co-operative fashion-it was quite clear that the matter was progressing but was still incomplete. That was some six months ago. I will have to seek information in order to get particular answers about the number of people working on the program, the resources applied to it and whether it has been possible to get agreement with the States. I indicate that the Commonwealth shares with Senator Georges a concern that the information should be gathered and that mechanisms should be put in place. ANSWER.PARA: When Senator Missen asked me a question earlier I had no material with me. My office has been able to pass to me a letter dated 11 October last from the Western Australian Minister for Health, the Honourable Ray Young. It indicates ways in which that State wishes to move to implement better arrangements for Aboriginal health. It may suit honourable senators if that letter is incorporated in Hansard so that it can add to the answers I have given to Senator Missen and Senator Georges. I seek leave to have it incorporated.
ABORIGINAL INVOLVEMENT IN HEALTH SERVICES: WESTERN AUSTRALIA

For many years the State Health Services in Western Australia have provided substantial employment for Aborigines. In 1972 the Community Health Services were established as a branch of the Public Health Department, for the specific purpose of improving Aboriginal health. Particular emphasis was given to the employment of Aborigines in the Service. All positions in the Service are open to Aboriginal people on the proviso that they have the ability and required qualifications to do the job. Furthermore, certain positions are held almost exclusively for Aborigines and include such jobs as Enrolled Nurse and Health Worker. Aborigines have also been encouraged to fill other positions such as storemen, cleaners, drivers, typists and nurses where qualifications permit.

Aboriginal communities have been involved in the selection of Aboriginal Health Workers serving with their communities and similarly consulted in the planning stages of programme development prior to surveys and health audits being carried out.

The Aboriginal population has had a significant influence on the objectives and aims of the Service since its inception in 1972. Much of this influence has been of an informal nature and although practical and effective, these informal mechanisms have attracted some criticism. It is my intention to have these mechanisms formalised and to increase and consolidate the structure of the Service so that Aborigines may exert greater influence on Aboriginal heath policy decisions. In practical terms this can be separated into two parts:

Mr Gabby Willaway was appointed Aboriginal Health Co-ordinator on October 27 1980. He has been directly responsible to the Branch Director for communicating with the many Aboriginal communities in the State and has the ability to influence policy decisions.

Mrs Sadie Canning, a nurse of considerable standing and formerly Director of Nursing of Leonora Hospital, and a respected Aboriginal, has taken an appointment as an Assistant Nursing Supervisor of Community Health Services.

Mrs Canning will advise the Service on improving communication with Aborigines especially in the area of Aboriginal female health problems. She will also influence education programmes involving cultural and nursing matters and be the senior person responsible for Aboriginal Health Workers.

13. The Department will continue to recruit trained Aboriginal State Registered Nurses and enrolled Nurses whenever possible and to deploy them to the best advantage of Aboriginal communities. At present five of the State Registered Nurses on the staff and all the Enrolled Nurses are Aboriginal.

Eighty-nine Aboriginal Health Workers are presently employed throughout the State. In the main they are nominated by Aboriginal communities. Over the past 18 months job descriptions and duties have been drawn up in consultation with the relative community so that both Service and community expectations are met. It is proposed to increase the numbers of Health Workers during the coming financial year.

Training is ''on the job'' supervised by local staff and also through formalised sessions by educators of the Department. General formal education is supported and encouraged and a course has been established by the Mt Lawley Campus-Western Australian College of Advanced Education.
A separate Industrial Award for Health Workers has been developed in Western Australia.

The Health Worker Award makes provision for a Special Category Health Worker. It is proposed to appoint a Health Worker Special Category in each region who will have responsibility for the implementation of this programme and convening of regional meetings as well as a role in the Health Worker education.

A camp nurse is an Aborigine living in a community and selected by that community to undertake some specific health tasks. They are not substantive employees of the Public Health Department. Each Camp Nurse is however paid an honorarium for their services. There are 75 such Camp Nurses in various communities throughout the State, who assist and advise their people as the need arises. The Camp Nurse receives some education and instructions from Service staff. Camp nurses are usually family women with some medical standing in the community.
It is proposed to establish a three tier system of Aboriginal Advisory Committees.
Health Workers to communicate on a day to day basis with Community Councils.

Depending on the wishes of the individual Aboriginal Councils it is also proposed that small local advisory committees be established with membership comprising of a health worker and Community representatives selected by the Councils. The aim being to provide Aboriginal Councils with a formal means of input to the Health Service.

A Committee to be established under the chairmanship of the Regional Medical Director of Public Health with representatives from the Region. The method of appointment of members of this Committee has not yet been determined.
A State Advisory Body, to be chaired by the Deputy Commissioner of Public Health and will contain prominent Aboriginal members holding responsible positions in other organisations.

This will greatly increase Aboriginal participation and involvement in health services in Western Australia, in keeping with the intentions of the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting held in Perth on February 26, 1982.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the sacking of a further 140 workers at the Kelvinator Australia Ltd plant in Adelaide. Is the Minister aware that the reason given by the company for these latest retrenchments is the flood of competitive imports on to the Australian market? Is the Minister also aware of a statement by the General Manager of Kelvinator, Mr Carlson, that the temporary subsidy assistance granted to the company will not restrain competitive imports of room air conditioners? I ask the Minister: Why does the Government disagree with the claims made by the company that the temporary tariff and quota assistance would have been a more effective way of combating the flood of cheap imports into Australia? When can we expect some positive and more direct action by the Federal Government to stop, once and for all, the destruction of our manufacturing industries by the inflow of cheap imports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator will be aware that the Government announced some little time ago that it was to provide assistance to Kelvinator, which matter he had raised by way of question in the Senate, as had other senators, following the report of the Temporary Assistance Authority. The Government's action was taken consistent with the recommendation of the Temporary Assistance Authority, which took the view that the procedure recommended by the company would not be effective as a means of providing additional protection because a large number of imports were already in the country. In other words, the imported summer stocks with which Kelvinator will be competing for this summer's trade are already imported. So for that reason the Temporary Assistance Authority recommended to the Government that the assistance should be by way of bounty.

ANSWER.PARA: In the event, the Government accepted the Authority's recommendation and granted assistance of $1.5m to Kelvinator by way of bounty. That is a quite generous level of assistance. Kelvinator has said that it is not as much as it would like, but it permits Kelvinator to cut the price of its product and to compete more adequately upon the market. In this matter the Government has been guided by the expert advice that it has received from the Temporary Assistance Authority. On the basis of that advice-which certainly seemed, on the face of it , correct-the Government believed that when the imports were already in the country there was little point in imposing some quantitative restriction which would have had no effect at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It relates to the increasing optimism about a United States of America economic recovery in 1983 and the consequential flow-on to other countries. In view of the very urgent need for Australia to be well placed to take the earliest advantage of world recovery through competitive exports and so create much needed employment opportunities, is the Government's appeal for moderation in wage increases and resistance to shorter working hours receiving a satisfactory response from the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

—I think there must be some disappointment in the breast of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations at the recent statement of Mr Dolan that he could not see much relevance in the requests for wage restraint in terms of maintaining employment in Australia. However, I think it would be better if I referred that question to Mr Macphee for reply. Clearly, it is highly desirable that there should be broad support within Australia on the part of employers and the trade union movement for the general propositions that Senator Walters has set out in her question. We wish to see a restraint on wage increases-not because we desire anyone to have less money but because we see such increases as being against the interests of maintaining employment in Australia and certainly against our interests in being able to take advantage of any increase in world trade when it occurs. So the matter raised by Senator Walters is serious. I shall refer it to Mr Macphee for him to respond on the basic point of the question, which is the attitude of the ACTU to calls for wage restraint.

The speech read as follows-

On 9 September I tabled in Parliament the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission containing its recommendations for the calendar year 1983, in response to the Government's guidelines. The Bill gives effect to the Government 's decisions on the Commission's financial recommendations for the distribution of funds for 1983, all of which have been accepted. As announced in the Government's guidelines statement, the Bill also provides for additional funds for 1982 programs, to help meet unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations.

The Bill now before the Senate reflects amendments made in another place which will establish the legal position regarding the interest of the Commonwealth and non-government school authorities where Commonwealth grants have been used for the purchase of major assets by non-government schools and the requirements regarding recovery of grants in the event of disposal of such assets. The amendments will also provide for funding on a per capita basis in 1982 of intensive English language programs for non-English speaking students who are newly arrived in Australia, bringing the total Commonwealth financial commitment to an estimated $11.1m this year. The Bill had already provided for the funding of this program on a per capita basis for 1983. The final costs of the 1982 and 1983 programs will therefore be determined by the actual number of eligible newly-arrived students.

The overall level of Commonwealth expenditure on schools programs in 1983 will be about $1241m, an increase of 3.7 per cent in real terms over 1982, all amounts being in 1983 outturn prices. The value of most programs will be at least maintained in real terms. For some programs there will be significant real increases.

Part II of the Bill contains provision for programs in government schools. To assist the States to overcome the financial difficulties which the Commission reported were facing government school systems, general recurrent grants for government schools will be increased by 2 per cent in real terms in 1983.

Funds for the capital grants program for government schools will be maintained at the same real level as in 1982. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that 10 per cent of the funds be distributed on the basis of certain indicators of the need to provide new pupil places. In addition, a general clause has been included in the Bill indicating that prior to the granting of funds to a State, the Commonwealth Minister must be satisfied with arrangements to identify projects to which Commonwealth funds are to be applied.

Part III of the Bill contains provision for programs in non-government schools. General recurrent grants to non-government schools have been increased in accordance with the policy which ties Commonwealth per capita grants to non- government schools to movements in the average cost of educating a student in a government school. The increases in commitments to non-government schools are also a result of increases in the subsidy rate to schools with the lowest recurrent resources, Group 3, from 38 per cent to 40 per cent of average government school standard costs. This fulfills the Government's commitment in the 1980 election to provide three levels of assistance for non-government school equal to 20 per cent, 30 per cent and 40 per cent of the average cost of educating a student in a government school. Almost 95 per cent of the increase in Commonwealth general recurrent grants in 1983 will be directed to those schools assessed as having lowest recurrent resources. On average such schools operate at recurrent resource levels some 30 per cent below those of government schools.

The Government endorses the Commission's intention to implement fully the previous decision to give consideration to income as well as expenditure in the assessment of non-government schools' subsidy categories and expects that the income checking procedure introduced on a limited basis in 1982 will be applied to all non-government schools eligible for Group 2 or Group 3 grants in 1983.

The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that eligibility for grants under the short-term emergency assistance program be extended to include any non-government school suffering a financial crisis caused by a sudden disaster.

For the general support element of the English as a second language program a further adjustment has been made to the distribution of program funds among the States to accord with the results of a recent national survey of students of non -English speaking background. Funds for the general support element for non- government schools have not been allocated on a State-by-State basis in the Bill . However, the Government intends that the allocations to Catholic schools in the various States and Territories will be in accordance with the recommended distribution in the Commission's Report. For non-Chatholic schools, the Government intends that State planning and finance committees should continue to be responsible for recommending the distribution of funds.

A significant new policy development encompassed in this Bill is the provision for the participation of children of below school age in the special education program. This also applies to the children in institutions and severely handicapped children's programs which are joint programs for both government and non-government schools. Joint programs are dealt with in Part IV of the Bill.

The allocation for the severely handicapped children's program has been increased by 25 per cent or $0.7m in real terms. The same real level of funds will be provided for the professional development program for 1983, including funds for education centres.

Allocations of grants for 1983 for the various programs for the States and the Northern Territory, are detailed in Schedules 1 to 11 of the Bill. These grants include provision of a prospective allowance for cost increases up to the end of 1983, in accordance with established government policy.

Grants for current programs for calendar year 1982 are adjusted under Part VI and Schedule 12 to help meet unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations. The additional cost of these adjustments is $45m.

An amendment has been made to the relevant clause in Part V of the Bill to enable the Commonwealth Minister to delegate all or any of his powers under the Act, other than that of delegation. This will improve the administration of programs and I will be considering carefully which matters should be retained for ministerial decision.

The provisions of this Bill demonstrate the Commonwealth's continuing commitment to high standards in all Australian schools, whether government or non-government. The increased overall level of support will enable further real improvements in the recurrent resource levels of all schools in Australia. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The speech read as follows-

I tabled in the Senate on 9 September, the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for 1983. This report was in response to the Government's guidelines for financial assistance for capital and equipment programs for universities and colleges of advanced education, and capital, equipment and recurrent programs for technical and further education institutions.

The primary purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 to implement the Government's decisions for 1983 on the financial recommendations made by the Commission, all of which have been accepted. Higher education recurrent grants for the 1982-84 triennium were determined by the Government in 1981 under the existing fixed triennial arrangements; however these are adjusted in the Bill to take account of recent Government decisions.

The legislation currently before the Senate takes account of recent amendments moved and accepted in the other place. The main reason for these amendments was to express all 1983 and 1984 allocations in the Bill in 1983 outturn prices, and to adjust 1982 recurrent grants where appropriate, to take account of recent Government decisions to provide additional funds in 1982 to help universities and colleges of advanced education meet the cost of recent salary increases.

The Government has agreed to provide an additional $34.7m to universities and colleges of advanced education in 1982. This is to help meet the cost of the seven per cent salary increase for all academics in higher education institutions recently recommended by the Academic Salaries Tribunal and approved by the Government, and recent salary increases for non-academic staff. However, consistent with the Government's decision to provide institutions with a prospective allowance for cost increases and to encourage them to live within that overall provision, the institutions themselves will be required to absorb a small part of the total cost of these salary increases.
In 1983, capital grants will total $163.3m of which $46.2m is for universities and colleges of advanced education, and $117.1m is for TAFE.
Equipment grants for 1983 total $69.2m for universities and colleges of advanced education and $10.4m for TAFE special equipment grants.
Recurrent grants for TAFE for 1983 amount to $106.1m.

Under the principal Act, certain institutions of higher education do not have recurrent grants appropriated for 1983 and 1984. Consolidation arrangements were recommended by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and were required by the Government's decisions arising from its Review of Commonwealth Functions. Consolidation arrangements have now been made for 26 of the 30 CAEs listed in the RCF decision. These include an amalgamation of the Institute of Early Childhood Development and Melbourne State College which has now been agreed by the Victorian Government. Funds have therefore been included in this legislation for the new amalgamated institution for 1983 and 1984.
Acceptable proposals have yet to be made in respect of Armidale CAE, Newcastle CAE, Milperra CAE and SCV Hawthorn.

In its report the Commission has noted the progress being made towards integration of the activities of the University of Newcastle and Newcastle CAE under a single governing body and towards consolidation of activities of SCV Hawthorn. It has suggested an appropriate approach to the consolidation of the activities of Milperra CAE. At Armidale there has also been some progress towards the development of arrangements to integrate the activities of the university with those of the college. The Government strongly supports the view of the Commission that 'higher education in Armidale and the surrounding region would benefit from an amalgamation of the university and the college' and looks forward to receiving an acceptable proposal from the New South Wales Government for such an amalgamation in the near future.
The Commonwealth Government has the responsibility for funding higher education and the responsibility to provide the best possible education services to the community.

The shift in Australian demography has required fundamental changes in the structure of higher education as so much of that system related to teacher education. The consolidation of these remaining institutions will complete the comprehensive re-organisation of higher education which was recommended by the CTEC and supported by the Review of Commonwealth Functions. It is essential that we enter calendar year 1983 with a re-organised system which will provide improved and expanded opportunities for higher education.

In the circumstances, the Government has decided that recurrent funds for all the institutions concerned, including the two universities, be put aside in a National Unallocated grant. These funds will be allocated by the Minister after advice from the Commission, when acceptable proposals are recommended in repect of the institutions which have not yet met the Commonwealth's requirements on consolidation. This means that acceptable proposals will need to be available by the end of 1982. I am anxious for the institutions and State governments concerned to produce acceptable proposals before the end of the year so that I can make these funds available.

In its report the Commission also considered the future of the Orange Agricultural College. The Commission has expressed support for an amalgamation of Orange Agricultural College and Mitchell CAE. While the Government considers there are advantages in the college entering into suitable arrangements with another institution, it is not specifying which other institution should be involved. The Government has agreed that separate funding for Orange Agricultural College should continue in 1983 but it expects that the college will move towards entering into an appropriate consolidation arrangement by January 1984. This means that the college and all concerned will certainly have until the end of 1983 to develop acceptable future arrangements. For this reason the Bill includes the 1984 recurrent funds for Orange Agricultural College in the National Unallocated Grant for Higher Education.

Higher education recurrent grants include provision for up to an additional $4. 4m in 1983 and $8.8m in 1984 to assist institutions to meet increased superannuation costs. These grants will assist with the cost of the new national superannuation scheme developed by the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee and the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations. This new scheme is designed to replace existing arrangements which give inadequate benefits to many staff. In addition, the grants will assist with the problem of meeting increased costs resulting from membership of State government superannuation schemes with a view to limiting these costs to the level of the new AVCC/FAUSA scheme.

Additional recurrent grants of $0.2m in 1983 and $0.3m in 1984 have been included in the Bill for the University of Melbourne to assist with the development of graduate teaching and research in management education. This results from the Government's consideration of the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Management Education-the Ralph Report. The provision of up to $4.6m as the Commonwealth contribution towards the construction of a building for the new graduate school of management at the University of Melbourne will be finalised following the Government's consideration of further proposals to be developed for the establishment and management of the school. These proposals will include the active co-operation and involvement of the Australian business community.

Following the Government's consideration of the evaluation of post-arrival programs and services for migrants by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, the Government decided that 15 per cent of TAFE particular purpose grants will be allocated for implementing programs of advanced English language instruction for migrants. The Commission is consulting with the States on the implementation of this program and will report shortly on the most appropriate method of giving full effect to the decision within 12 months.

TAFE capital grants include financial assistance for the construction of seven major building projects and the design of a further two building projects under the new three-year $60m National Priority Projects program.

The first instalment of this new three-year program, which is included in the Bill, will be $13.9m for 1983. This level of activity recognises that expenditure on new projects is inevitably less in the first year than occurs in later years. However, the Commission's recommendations provide for the full expenditure of the $60 allocated over the three years 1983-85.
