PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The matters with which this Bill and its companion measures deal have been the subject of considerable public and political debate.
In bringing the measures before the Parliament the Government demonstrates once again its clear commitment to do what it can to establish and uphold a fair system of taxation in this country.

The Treasurer has on behalf of the Government in recent years brought before the Parliament a very wide range of Bills designed so that those who would seek to escape their fair share of taxation do not succeed in that purpose.

By this legislation the Government complements its earlier proscription of schemes to evade the payment of legally payable company tax by a Bill that will recover evaded company tax from the principal beneficiaries of earlier evasion of that kind.
In doing this we have sought to achieve a reasonable balance between all the various, and often conflicting, interests and considerations that seem to attend the more significant of taxation issues.

Our normal and general reluctance to introduce taxation legislation having any retrospective element has, on this occasion, been tempered by the competing consideration of overall perceptions as to the equity and fairness of our taxation system and the distribution of the tax burden. We are also dealing here with recoupment of tax which was clearly the subject of illegal evasion.
The Government believes that the public is clearly of the view that tax evaded in the course of pre-tax strips of company profits should be recovered for public purposes.

The legislation that is now before the Senate will result in both of the groups that have benefited financially from the evasion of company tax-vendors and promoters-being called on to make restitution.
But in establishing by this Bill the rules under which accounts are to be settled, the Government has been anxious to ensure that the matter proceeds on a properly measured basis.
I believe that this Bill observes these principles.

Since this legislation was first foreshadowed by the Treasurer on 25 July 1982, the Government's intention has always been that the tax recouped should be that tax that remains unpaid as a result of arrangements which have resulted in illegal evasion of tax.
Tax that may have been avoided either by the former owners of companies or by the companies themselves is not the subject of this legislation.

That point needs to be made clear not only so that the ambit of the Bill is properly understood, but also so that some of the wilder claims about the numbers of companies that have been stripped of untaxed profits can be seen to be as unfounded as they are.

Where companies were simply stripped of profits that have borne all the company -including undistributed profits-tax payable on them, there has been no evasion of tax and the legislation will not apply.
Nor will it apply to the taxed profits element in the case of a strip of both taxed and untaxed company profits.
Only the tax on the untaxed profits is the subject of the Bill.

But let me remind the Senate that, with effect from 27 May 1981 when we brought in the new general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, vendor-shareholders are to be taxed on any profits liberated to them in the course of a dividend strip or other similar strip of company profits .
I turn now to those situations where companies which have been sold had themselves entered into tax avoidance schemes.

In speaking about this area, let me immediately lay at rest a notion entertained by some people that the legislation will recover tax that was escaped only because of the involvement of the companies in avoidance schemes.
It will not. The only tax to be recovered under the legislation is tax that was legally payable, and the payment of which has been illegally evaded.

This follows from the provisions in the legislation that make recoupment tax payable only where company tax legally payable remains unpaid, former owners having had the opportunity to contest the commissioner's contention that company tax is payable.

If the commissioner, with full knowledge of the situation, has allowed a deduction created under a tax avoidance scheme, that would conclude the matter, and there would now be no claim for tax based on challenge to that scheme.
The Bill before the Senate is set against the background of three broad situations in which companies have been sold and company tax legally payable remains unpaid.
The first and most obvious one is a straight-out asset strip with a clear intention of leaving the company unable to pay its tax liabilities.

Included within that category are those situations where a company is sold after it has been assessed to tax by the commissioner following his rejection of an earlier avoidance scheme that the company had entered into.

A second category is the one where after the sale of the company the company has been put into what purports to be a tax avoidance scheme but it is one that, in substance, is part of an arrangement to render the company unable to pay its tax.

And the third situation is one where after the sale of the shares the company was also put into an avoidance scheme which could reasonably have been regarded at the time as being effective of its simple tax avoidance purpose.
In relation to each of the second and third categories I note that the commissioner's action in contesting the legal efficacy of the schemes is not something that he is only now doing.

He has had the widest range of avoidance schemes under challenge and, as I have already indicated, a situation of any possible relevance to the Bill would only arise when, and to the extent that, when the courts do pass judgment on the schemes, they find them to fail at law, so that tax is legally payable.
The Bill before the Senate puts the first and second categories within the scope of the recoupment tax.
Each clearly has an element of fraud attaching to the arrangement at some point or another.

The third category is different, as it can fairly be put that, because the avoidance scheme could not be said to be part of the arrangement to leave the company unable to meets its tax liabilities, an element of fraud is not present.

Accordingly, there is a specific provision in the Bill to the effect that if the target company was the subject of a post-sale attempted avoidance scheme which, objectively viewed, would have had reasonable prospects of succeeding in its purpose, and the scheme is not part of, or associated with, the stripping arrangement so that the arrangement carried no purpose of rendering the company unable to pay, there will be no recoupment tax liability.

In line with that, the recoupment legislation will also not apply where there was a pre-saled avoidance scheme which, though ultimately shown to be unsuccessful, might reasonably have been expected to have worked, if at the time of the sale the commissioner had not raised an assessment rejecting the claims made under the scheme.
Mr President, I turn now to the details of the Bill.
Vendors

The measures to collect evaded tax are to operate on strips of untaxed profits that were carried out between 1 January 1972 and 4 December 1980, when the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 dealt a decisive blow to such schemes.

Just as the legislation applies to arrangements that have a purpose of rendering a company unable to pay its tax, so the present Bill will declare that it is to operate only where there has been an arrangement that had the effect that a company was rendered unable to pay its company tax.
The other precise tests of the legislation are also of an objective nature, helping to make clear its field of operation, and I now outline them, taking first the simpler forms of company structure.
The Treasurer said in his statement of 25 July that the legislation would apply where all the shares in a company were sold.
Scheme promoters needed to have total control of a company before they could effect the strip that was a part of the overall arrangement.

However, it was possible for them to do this where less than the entire ownership was acquired and the Bill accordingly, on the basis of company law provisions, makes it a condition for its application that there was a sale of shares carrying more than 90 per cent of the voting power in the target company.

Typically, schemes of the kind dealt with by this Bill involved a sale of shares and the Bill treats for what it is, a sale and purchase of shares, an arrangement under which former owners mortgaged their shares in return for receipt of a loan, and then, as pre-arranged, defaulted in repayment so that the shares were forfeited or otherwise fell into the hands of the promoter.
The loan proceeds were of course effectively the sale price of the shares and the legislation will apply accordingly.

Yet again, the Bill provides that its basic test of disposal of shares carrying more than 90 per cent of the voting power of the company will be operative in those situations where shares are sold by a person who had formerly exercised control by reason of holding an office such as that of governing director.

Another important test is framed so that it is clear that the legislation will apply only where the vendor-shareholders and other former owners actually derived a benefit from the evasion of the company's tax.

This is achieved by a provision that requires that the total consideration for the sale of the shares in the company exceeded its net assets as reduced by any actual or contingent company tax liability on income derived up to the time of sale of the shares.

To put it another way, the test is one that puts into legal terms the concept that the sale price for the company was such that it was evident that company tax on the amount of then apparent profits simply would not be paid.

A person who pays, say, $90,000 for shares in a company that has traded for part of the income year and earned $100,000, which is what the company has in the bank, cannot be regarded as in a position to pay the $46,000 company tax payable on a taxable income of $100,000.

The liability of former owners of a company under the legislation will not arise until the company's liability has been established by assessment, rights of objection and appeal against that assessment have either not been exercised or have been exhausted, and tax remains unpaid.

In this regard, former owners of a company will not be called on to effect recoupment of the company tax under this legislation until after they have had an opportunity to contest the basic assessment of that tax.

The Commissioner of Taxation has already issued many notices of assessment in respect of the companies concerned, but due to the fact that some have been returned unclaimed, and to other circumstances, these notices are a less than satisfactory foundation for tax claims on the former owners.

As soon as practicable after this legislation is passed, therefore, a copy of the already-issued notice of assessment will in each case be sent to all former shareholders, the only qualification being that the person's whereabouts is known or, in the case of a company, that it is not dormant.

Further, to ensure that the group that can object on the company's behalf is sufficiently representative, the representative group, each of whom is to get a copy of the company assessment, is to include up to 5 further people who were owners of the company further along a chain of ownership.
The representative group, acting by majority, may under the Bill then appoint one of their number who will be able to exercise the rights of objection and appeal open to the company.

The obligation of former owners to meet any late payment penalty owing by the company will be measured only from the date that would be the due date for payment if the company assessment had been served on the day that the copy is sent.

The Treasurer said in his statement of 25 July that the legislation will not apply where the reason for non-payment of company tax is that a company has suffered commercial misadventure in the hands of its new owners, following its sale at a commercially realistic price.
To make that clear, the legislation specifies that it will apply only where the company did not, after the sale, carry on the same business as it had carried on beforehand.
Where the various threshold tests are all met each vendor-shareholder will, at base, be liable to effect recoupment of his or her share of the evaded tax.
That amount will be fixed according to the vendor's share of the total consideration for the sale of shares in the company.

In noting that the vendor-shareholders will be liable to recoup the total amount of the evaded company tax, undiminished by the part of that tax taken as a fee by those who promoted the scheme and stripped the company, I also observe that payments of recoupment tax by the promoter's group in a particular case will reduce the amount of recoupment tax payable by the former owners.

I note that recoupment tax obligations will extend to vendor-shareholders in a company who sold shares and thereby, in association with other shareholders concerned, transferred control in yet another company which was stripped of untaxed company profits.
A sale of shares in a holding company that carried ownership of a series of subsidiary companies with untaxed profits is an example.

Whether a sale of shares took place in one of these more complex situations, or in the simple case I dealt with earlier, some of the vendor-shareholders will have been companies or trusts through which people held ownership of the stripped companies, and there could also have been more lengthy chains of ownership.

The broad aim of the legislation is to effect recoupment at the earlier practicable and appropriate stage along a chain of ownership but where, in defined circumstances, that cannot be achieved the Bill has provisions for tracing through, broadly on the basis of rights to capital, the liability from one level to another, so that ultimately it rests on the people who indirectly owned the stripped companies.

Persons who at a primary or secondary level are liable to the recoupment tax that is being formally imposed as a technique for recovering the evaded tax will be issued with a notice of assessment setting out the amounts each is liable to pay.

A recipient of such a notice will of course have the usual rights of objection and appeal against a recoupment tax assessment and, if the tax remains unpaid 30 days after the notice is issued, the unpaid amount will thereafter attract late payment penalty at the rate of 20 per cent per annum.
On review, we have concluded that that rate, rather than the earlier-announced rate of 30 per cent would be appropriate.

Associated with that, a separate Bill that I will shortly introduce will implement the earlier-announced decision to propose a doubling-from 10 per cent to 20 per cent-in the rate of penalty for late payment of income tax.

This further Bill will have the effect that late payment penalty begins to accrue as soon as is practicable at the higher rate of 20 per cent in the basic assessments of company tax issued or to be re-issued in respect of the stripped companies concerned.

In noting that unpaid undistributed profits tax is within the scope of the recoupment legislation, I observe that in harmony with existing provisions in the income tax law the former owners of a company may arrange instead to pay tax themselves on the same basis as if the company had distributed enough in dividends to escape a liability to undistributed profits tax.

A feature of the Bill of broad significance is the offer of limited time to pay to former owners who decide not to contest their liability under the legislation and who make satisfactory arrangements with the Commissioner of Taxation for payment of the unpaid company tax on which their liability to pay recoupment tax would be based.

The general background is, of course, that, as the Treasurer has indicated, the Government hopes that former owners will simply arrange to pay the company tax and the Bill is structured so that any payment of company tax by them will not operate to diminish the promoters' liability to the tax in respect of the stripped company concerned.
The kind of arrangement for which the Bill makes provision is one where the former owners agree to pay the unpaid company tax in instalments over a period- normally of up to 12 months.

They would, at the time of making an arrangement with the Commissioner, need to make an initial payment of part of the tax and, if the arrangement for subsequent payments was adhered to, they would not be liable for any late payment penalty. Nor would they be liable to pay recoupment tax.

The provision in the Bill for this time to pay recognizes that some persons who will be liable under the legislation may need to dispose of assets and takes into account such things as possible effects on employment that immediate payment of the tax could have.

Another provision in the Bill will mean that if the underlying company tax liability is contested by some of the former owners of the company, but others wish immediately to pay their share of the evaded tax, they can do so without incurring any liability for late payment penalty that would arise from the delay brought about by the company assessment being put into dispute.
Earlier-foreshadowed provisions to guard against divestment of assets in an attempt to frustrate the operation of the recoupment legislation are another feature of the Bill.
Amoung further provisions of note are measures-
to adopt the machinery and collection provisions of the income tax law;

to ensure that, secrecy provisions of the tax law notwithstanding, persons liable to vendors recoupment tax are able to get details of the basis on which their liability was calculated and, to assist them in any personal pursuit of promoters for compensation, of the ways in which their company was stripped;
to make appropriate adjustments in a former owner's liability where other amounts of, or representing, the unpaid company tax are paid;
to deal with situations where a stripped company has ceased to exist; and
to give the Commissioner of Taxation authority not to pursue liability in particular circumstances, including where a former owner's liability under the legislation is under $100.
Promoters
Mr President, I turn now to a discussion of the liability of promoters and other strippers to assist in making good the evasion of tax that has occurred.
Our appointment of a special prosecutor, and the work that he will carry out, can be expected to make some contribution, but the Government is not content to let it rest there.
This legislation will also place a liability on those who were on the post-sale side of these schemes.
The popular conception of who is a promoter of schemes to strip companies of untaxted profits does not help us all that much in framing the kind of tests which the legislation must express.
The connection of promoters with the schemes they devised or marketed was one that varied substantially from promoter to promoter and is not capable of simple expression.

Accordingly, the Bill contains a series of formal tests that describe which persons are to be treated as 'promoters' under the legislation or, in the terms used in the Bill, as being members of the eligible promoters class.

Not only are promoters, as popularly understood, to be put into the eligible promoters class, but so too are those people, typically members of a promoter's family, who directly or indirectly had ownership rights in the companies and trusts through which promoters normally operated, and in that way received or stood to receive benefits.

Included within the eligible promoters class will be those who purchased shares from vendor-shareholders, were shareholders or directors of a purchasing company , were beneficiaries or trustees of a purchasing trust or were directors of a corporate trustee.
Also included will be legal or beneficial owners through one or more further companies or trusts in a chain of ownership extending behind the purchasing company or trust.

Similar provision will be made where the promoter's formal connection was as agent for the purchaser or as broker, and where a person who was an associate of a purchaser from vendor-shareholders gave financial assistance in the purchase of the shares.

If by a loan that had the real character of a distribution of income or capital a person stripped moneys from a company or trust that is in the eligible promoters class, the person will also be included in the class.
The Bill places on all the persons who are in the eligible promoters class in relation to a stripped company, a joint and several liablity for recoupment tax in relation to that company.

That means that each person in the class is fundamentally, but subject to rights of contribution and apportionment of liablity that I will mention shortly , liable for the whole of the recoupment tax attaching to that group of persons.

That feature, allied with the necessity to put persons into the eligible promoters class on the basis of their formal legal connections, for example as shareholder in a company, could lead to some people such as an office secretary being made liable when she does not either really participate in or benefit from the scheme otherwise than as an employee.

Simply for that combination of reasons, there is provision in the Bill under which a person can achieve exclusion from the eligible promoters class by obtaining a Federal court declaration excluding the person from the class.

As another aspect of the joint and several liability on persons in an eligible promoters class, a person who has in consequence paid some or all of the recoupment tax attaching to that class may seek through the courts an appropriate contribution from other members of the class.

While that basic consequence of joint and several liability is to remain a feature of the Bill, we have been pursuaded that a person who, under the joint and several concept, is sued by the Commissioner ought not to be required first to pay the tax before he or she seeks contribution from the others.
This could be particularly so where the appropriate share of the person sued is a relatively small part of the total Bill.

Accordingly, the Bill contains provision under which a person in the promoters class who is sued by the Commissioner for unpaid promoters recoupment tax may act to have other members of the class joined as co-defendants to the recovery suit.

Where that option is exercised the court will, having regard to levels of participation and benefit enjoyed or to be enjoyed, have power to determine how much of the unpaid amount it is just and equitable that the person sued, and each of the persons joined, should be liable to pay as recoupment tax.

The basic tests for determining whether 'promoters' are liable to recoupment tax will accord with those for vendor-shareholders, except that there will not be the test, applicable to vendors, that measures sale proceeds against the pre- sale net assets of the target company.

The effect of the Bill will be that the 'promoters' group will generally be liable to recoupment tax equal to 20 per cent of vendors' liability, that is, 20 per cent of the total of unpaid primary company tax, any unpaid division 7 tax and any late payment penalty accruing after vendors are notified of the company liability.
I mention that 20 per cent reflects the average amount of evaded tax that promoters took as fees for the service they provided to vendor-shareholders.

However, in those pre-tax profits strip cases where vendors are not liable to recoupment tax-for example, where a tax provision was paid to a promoter who did not use it to pay the company tax-the relevant 'promoters' group will be liable for recoupment tax equal to the whole of such unpaid company tax.

It has been put to us that this fixed percentage liability on those in the promoters group could operate inappropriately where, in a particular case, the fee charged was at a substantially lower level.
This could, for example, happen where the amount of profits stripped from a particular company was large, and the fee was, as a percentage of profits, somewhat lower.
To meet this situation the Bill will place a ceiling on the total recoupment tax liability that attaches to the promoters class for a particular scheme.

That ceiling will be the amount of the gross fee charged by the promoter, that is, in the simple case the difference between the net worth of the company at the time of sale (now unpaid tax liabilities aside) and the consideration for the purchase of the shares.

I note the point that this ceiling is expressed in terms of total recoupment tax liability, such as in a case where there were a number of unpaid company assessments for the target company, perhaps involving more than one year of income.

Of necessity, given that there was typically no dissection of fee between such different company tax liabilities of a company or, in a case where accumulated profits were also involved, between the amount charged for pre-tax and accumulated profits, the fee limitation expressed in the Bill is in terms of the total fee regardless of how it was calculated or on which profits it might have been based.

For those situations where the 'promoters' share of the evaded tax is 20 per cent, the Bill retains a full liability on the vendors, but to the extent that the 'promoters' group pays its 20 per cent share, the recoupment tax liability of the former owners of the company concerned will be correspondingly reduced.
Mr President, that completes my explanation at this stage of the main features of the Bill.

An explanatory memorandum providing a detailed explanation of the various measures contained in the Bill has been made available to honourable senators, the main memorandum being complemented by a supplementary memorandum that deals particularly with changes made to the Bill during its consideration by the House of Representatives.
It will be apparent, I believe, that the Government, after careful consideration of the many points of view that have been put about this legislation, is sticking to it and its basic concepts.
It will be clear that we have positively responded to reasonable criticisms of the measures as announced by the Treasurer and as originally introduced in the other place.
In that light, I commend that Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

In speaking to the Bills I have just introduced to recover tax evaded in the course of 'bottom-of-the-harbour' strips of untaxed company profits I mentioned that I would be introducing a further Bill to double the rate of penalty for late payment of income tax.

This Bill-which was on introduction in the House of Representatives was titled the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Additional Tax) Bill-will achieve that purpose, not just for companies that were stripped of assets but also for all individuals and other companies that are late in paying their income tax.
It will also provide for an income tax deduction for payments of promoters recoupment tax made under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill.
I now turn to details of this Bill.

On 10 August 1982 the Treasurer (Mr Howard) announced the Government's intention to propose an increase from 10 per cent per annum to 20 per cent per annum in the rate of penalties payable under the various taxation laws for late payment of tax.

At the same time he gave some details of the Government's intention to introduce a system for payment of interest on a refund of tax that occurs as a result of a successful objection or appeal by a taxpayer.
By this Bill, the income tax law will be amended to increase the rate of late payment penalty for late payment of income tax and related amounts.
The increase to 20 per cent will not, however, take effect until two months after this Bill has become law.

The new rate of penalty tax will apply in respect of the late payment of assessed income tax, withholding tax in interest and dividends paid to non- residents of Australia, mining withholding tax and tax instalment deductions made by an employer from salaries or wages paid to employees.

The Bill also proposes a corresponding increase in the rate of additional tax payable where the taxable income of a company has been underestimated and the company has thereby been enabled to pay reduced instalments of company tax.
The existing income tax law empowers the Commissioner of Taxation to remit all or part of an amount of late payment penalty where that is judged to be appropriate.

Where there is an objection or appeal against an assessment and the Commissioner accepts that the taxpayer has a genuine difference of opinion about his or her tax liability, the present general administrative practice of the Commissioner is, in the exercise of that power to remit, to enter into an arrangement with the taxpayer to remit all late payment penalty in the event that the taxpayer is not successful in his objection or appeal. This arrangement is on the basis that the taxpayer pays one-half of the tax in dispute pending the outcome of the objection or appeal-it has been called a 50-50 arrangement.

This Bill will re-express the power given to the Commissioner of Taxation to remit late payment penalty, so that this particular approach to the handling of disputed income tax liabilities will not be available in future.

The Commissioner will of course continue to be empowered to remit late payment penalty where there are special circumstances, such as adverse business conditions or other factors beyond the control of the taxpayer.
Although the remission power is to be altered for the future, existing 50-50 arrangements will be allowed to continue according to their terms.

I also make the point that under the legislation we propose that a person who has a genuine dispute about liability will be able to pay to the Commissioner one-half of the disputed tax and obtain an extension of time for payment of the balance on the basis that, if the taxpayer wins the contest, he or she will be paid interest when the 50 per cent is refunded but, if the taxpayer loses, the Commissioner will be entitled to recover the remaining 50 per cent subject to late payment penalty of 20 per cent from the date when the assessment became payable.
It has not been practicable to include in this Bill the measures necessary to provide for the payment of interest to taxpayers.

We are committed to these measures and, although it has not been possible to prepare the necessary legislation for introduction in these sittings, a Bill incorporating these measures will be introduced early in the autumn sittings.

It also remains the Government's intention to introduce in the autumn sittings legislation dealing with late payment penalties in respect of sales tax and other taxes administered by the Commissioner of Taxation.

As I have explained in my second reading speech on introduction of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill, there is to be payable by promoters of schemes to strip companies of pre-tax profits a share of the company tax evaded by those companies. This share is to be collected by imposition of a promoters recoupment tax on a promoters taxable amount and will be limited to the gross fee charged on the acquisition of the target company.

Such a fee would generally have the character of income in the hands of the promoter concerned, and it can be said that collection of both income tax and the recoupment tax would amount to a double imposition.
The Government sees the strength of that argument.

The broad notion behind imposition of the recoupment tax on promoters is that the promoters should never have benefited by the evasion of company tax, and that the recoupment tax will return from them the fees that represent their share of the evaded tax.
To put it another way, the promoters fee that was received will by reason of the promoters recoupment tax, be required to be paid back.

In these circumstances, the Government believes it to be appropriate that the income tax law should be made to apply to promoters' own liability to income tax as though they had never received the amounts that they in fact pay back as recoupment tax.

Accordingly, the Government proposes by this Bill to allow as an income tax deduction for a person the amount that he or she pays as promoters recoupment tax, or as a contribution towards the promoters recoupment tax that another member of the particular promoters class has paid.
This deduction will be allowable for the year in which the shares in the target company were purchased, but will not be allowed to give rise to a carry-forward loss.
Finally, Mr President, I mention the review that has been going on in recent months of monetary and other penalties contained in the various taxation laws.
We intend, again in the autumn sittings, to introduce further legislation to increase the effectiveness of the other penalty provisions of the taxation laws.

Part of the review of penalties has focused on the rate of additional tax payable in cases involving international profit shifting arrangements, where avoidance that would otherwise occur has been eliminated by the new legislation brought in by this Government.

The Government has not overlooked its undertaking given in the Senate earlier this year that the level of additional tax applicable to such profit shifting arrangements would be reviewed, and the results of that review will be announced shortly.
An explanatory memorandum giving technical explanations of provisions of the Bill has been made available to honourable senators and I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The objective of this Bill is to give legislative recognition to basic human rights and freedoms and to provide remedies for their enforcement.

In November 1973, then-Senator Murphy introduced a virtually identical Bill into this chamber. Unfortunately, the Bill was not proceeded with in the Senate and when Parliament was prorogued in February 1974, it lapsed. It was not re- introduced before the double dissolution was called in 1975.

Like Senator Murphy's Bill, this Bill is based upon the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which was adopted by the United Nations on 10 December 1948, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1966.

There has been a great deal of debate in legal and political circles about the extent of Commonwealth power to implement such international covenants. Earlier this year in the Racial Discrimination Act case, the High Court of Australia provided the basis for optimism that the Commonwealth Government has the constitutional authority to legislate with regard to matters of genuine international concern. The existence of a bona fide international covenant, such as the Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, is an important element in determining the extent of that ''genuine international concern''.

It is because of the Racial Discrimination Act case and because neither the Government nor the Australian Labor Party has shown any inclination to act, that the Australian Democrats have decided to proceed with a Human Rights Bill at this time. The Government's 1981 Human Rights Commission Act is a toothless tiger. The Commission has no coersive powers-it can only report and recommend on human rights problems. It cannot take even the most flagrant breaches of human rights to court and it has no jurisdiction at all in relation to the States, where some of the worst abuses of human rights occur.

Similarly, the Labor Party has shown no interest in effective human rights legisation since its 1973 Bill. It seems content to wait wistfully for the day when it returns to power, leaving the human rights issue to languish on the shelf.

If ever there was a case for a matter of principle to override the considerations of party politics, it is the case for human rights. It is a national disgrace that our Constitution has no provisions to protect the fundamental rights and liberties of our citizens; that no serious attempt has been made to rectify that omission legislatively; and that Australia's ratification of the international covenant, which finally came in August 1980, was subject to so many reservations that the international legality of our ratification is unclear.

The Covenant on Civil and Political Rights covers such rights as freedom of speech, freedom of assembly and association, freedom of religion and conscience, freedom of movement, the rights of a person charged with a criminal offence, the protection of individual privacy, the right to vote and hold public office, and so on. These rights and freedoms are set out in this Bill, which would be binding on each State and Territory as well as the Commonwealth.

Equally importantly, the Bill would provide the machinery to enforce those rights and protect those freedoms. Aggrieved persons would have access to the courts and the Australian Human Rights Commissioner will have the power to investigate breaches of human rights, either on his or her own initiative or on receipt of a complaint. Furthermore, unlike the impotent Human Rights Commission we have today, the Commissioner under this Bill will have the power to take legal proceedings on behalf of an aggrieved person.

In some respects, this Bill modifies the 1973 Bill to take account of developments which have occurred in the intervening ten years. Many of these changes are simply drafting alterations to accord with current usage. More important, however, are the new versions of sections on the rights of the family , religious freedom and sexual preference.

The 1973 Bill provoked substantial opposition from lobbying groups which felt that there was inadequate protection for the family. This Bill recognises the family as the 'natural and fundamental unit of society', entitled to the protection of society and of the law. This provision is consistent with Article 23 of the international covenant.

The 1973 Bill was opposed by some religious groups objecting to section 10 (4) of that Bill which would have permitted the Government to limit religious freedom with 'reasonable regulations as to time, place and manner'. The corresponding section in section 9 (4) of this Bill does not contain the controversial phrase. The revised section is an attempt to permit necessary limitations on dangerous activities which parade under the cover of 'religious beliefs', and yet to prohibit government interference with genuine religious practices.

Section 18 of the Bill deals with the freedom to manifest one's sexual preference without unlawful interference or discrimination. Although no corresponding section is in the international covenant, it is my view that such a provision is consistent with the spirit of the Covenant and would be constitutional. Freedom of sexual preference would be subject only to such limitations as are prescribed by law, and are reasonably necessary to protect public safety or public health or to preserve the rights of others.

Part V of the Bill establishes an Australian Human Rights Council, which would assume the educational functions which are now carried out by the existing Human Rights Commission. As I have already indicated, the enforcement powers under the Act, which would be considerably greater than existing methods of enforcement of human rights violations, would rest with the Commissioner. These new enforcement powers are contained in Parts III and IV of the Bill.

Mr President, I believe that Australians have waited too long for the Commonwealth Government's protection of their basic human rights. They have suffered too long under the haphazard protection which is provided by the common law and those random legislative and constitutional provisions which may happen to touch on an area of human rights.

The Australian Democrats would prefer, of course, that a Bill of Rights were written into the Australian Constitution. But, the road to constitutional amendment is difficult, long and uncertain. In the absence of a constitutionally -entrenched Bill of Rights, this legislation-which will be binding on Federal, State and local officials-represents the best available means of giving effect to the International Covenant and providing protection for the fundamental rights of all Australians. We hope that this statutory Bill of Rights will pave the way for a constitutional amendment in due course.

A great deal of effort has gone into the area of human rights, by the Labor Party in its 1973 Bill, by the Liberal Party in its Human Rights Commission Bills of 1977, 1979 and 1981 and by the Australian Democrats with the Bill in its current form. I therefore respectfully urge my Senate colleagues of all political persuasions to lend their support to the passage of this Bill so that the rights of all Australians will have a firmer basis in law.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not oppose Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83. Since the Appropriation Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on Budget night, it has become quite clear that the Budget estimates given in association with those Bills are, for whatever reason, wildly erroneous and that the deficit, officially estimated at that stage at $1.674 billion, will almost certainly blow out to something in excess of $3 billion and possibly reach a figure close to $4 billion. It has also become much clearer since the Bills were introduced into the Parliament that the Australian economy is headed for, and indeed has now reached, its most seriously recessed stage since the mid-1930s. Unemployment has risen drastically in the couple of intervening months and is clearly headed for much higher levels . Initial confirmation of the continuing increase in unemployment will undoubtedly appear before the end of this week.

SPEECH.PARA: Interest rates, having a couple of weeks ago taken a small flutter downwards in some areas, are now clearly on the way up again. The degree to which the money market was fooled by the inaccurate estimates of the public sector borrowing requirement contained in the Budget may or may not have been a factor in the temporary flutter downwards of interest rates. But, however that may be, interest rates are clearly on the way up again and there is no possibility whatsoever in the foreseeable future of the sensitive business and home borrowing interest rates coming down. Indeed, if we were to believe the assertion frequently repeated by this Government in earlier years that there is a direct linkage between the size of the public sector borrowing requirement and the level of interest rates, we would have to conclude that interest rates will go up. Of course, that simplistic assertion was never correct. There are always other variables which affect interest rates, but the magnitude of the likely Budget deficit blowout is such that it is conceivable that interest rates will rise to even higher levels for that reason alone.

The release of the September quarter consumer price index figure revealed the highest annual inflation rate that we have had since the December quarter of 1976 and, incidentally, an annual inflation rate which is higher than that which prevailed when this Government came to office. A simple but stark reminder of the failure of the economic policies of this Government is the fact that since it came to office the number of unemployed has doubled and, as well, the inflation rate has gone up. Plenty of other inept governments have managed to double unemployment levels. The Reagan Administration and the Thatcher Administration have almost succeeded in doubling unemployment, but only Malcolm Fraser has been able to double unemployment and push inflation up as well. In all of the other countries in which in recent times unemployment levels have rocketed, inflation has come down. The true measure of Malcolm Fraser's achievement as an economic manager is the fact that only he has managed to double the number of people unemployed and push inflation up as well. For the first time in more than 20 years, the Australian economy is actually shrinking. Although the official figures have not yet emerged, beyond doubt the volume of real gross domestic product is shrinking. At this moment, and almost certainly for this financial year as a whole, negative real GDP growth will be recorded- for the first time since the recession of 1961.

The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Government attribute this economic disaster entirely to overseas factors, to external influences beyond the control of any Australian government, and say that nothing can be done. They adopt the completely negative position that nothing can be done until the world situation improves, that the most prudent course for any Australian government to pursue is that of ensuring that whenever that world upturn does occur we will be well placed to take advantage of it. The Australian Labor Party categorically rejects that negative thinking and admission of failure. Any government that is so bereft of ideas, so abject in its surrender, as to live by that sort of view is not fit to hold office.

It might also be worth observing that the present Government view, or assertion , that the depression is caused by factors beyond the control of any Australian government, contradicts sharply the following view expressed by the present Prime Minister in January 1975 in addressing the ANZAAS conference:

When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying, 'we can overcome'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The present Prime Minister said that in January 1975. That is what he said when he was in Opposition. When he is in government, presiding over the blackest depression we have seen since the mid 1930s, over the only period of negative economic growth that we have seen since 1961, he says by contrast: ' This is due to external factors that are absolutely beyond our control'. To the Prime Minister, on any matter, there is no such thing as a belief in anything, whether it concerns the ethics of tax dodging or the ethics of ripping off government programs such as the National Employment and Training System. There is no such thing as a belief. There is only ephemeral political convenience. In 1975 it was politically convenient to say that external influences were irrelevant. In 1982 it is politically convenient to say that external economic influences are the only relevant factor.

SPEECH.PARA: Something which is far more important than the Prime Minister's habitual inconsistency, which I think is well known to everyone by now, is the simple fact that Australia's performance right now is poor when compared with the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the leading countries in that Organisation. Our performance throughout the second half of the 1970s has been poor. Contrary to the rhetoric of the Government, the statistical record shows that Australia fared very badly in the second half of the 1970s relative to the OECD as a whole and in particular in comparison with the leading OECD countries. Australia's performance compared with leading OECD countries is still poor. I do not want to cite too many statistics but I think it is essential to cite some.

For the five calendar years from 1976 to 1980 inclusive-the source of the figures to which I refer is the OECD Economic Outlook No. 30 which was published in December 1981-the average rate of real growth in gross domestic product in Australia was 2.6 per cent. In the OECD as a whole it was 3.4 per cent. That was not startlingly high but it was significantly higher than ours. In leading OECD countries, such as Japan, the average growth rate was 5.1 per cent. In Austria it was 3.5 per cent and in West Germany it was 3.6 per cent. All of those figures were significantly higher than the figure which Australia recorded. Throughout the same period-the five calendar years from 1976 to 1980 inclusive- Australia's average rate of unemployment was 5.7 per cent. It was not much higher but it was still higher than the unemployment rate for the OECD as a whole which was 5.3 per cent. It was very much higher than the rate of 3.1 per cent in Japan, the rate of 1.9 per cent in Austria, where at no stage in those five years did it exceed 2.1 per cent, and the rate of 3.4 per cent in West Germany.

The recession in Australia prior to this recession bottomed not in 1974 or 1975 , as it did in the rest of the industrialised world, but in 1977. Only for a very short period, which was associated with heavy investment in resources development 18 months to 30 months ago, was Australia's growth performance as good as that of the industrialised world as a whole. I refer of course to the much vaunted resources boom which was talked up recklessly by the Government for electoral purposes in 1980. The same Government now bewails one of the unintended but inevitable consequences of the reckless talking up of the resources boom-that is, the very high level of wage growth which has probably ceased to prevail now but which prevailed through most of 1981 and a good deal of 1982.

The most recent available statistics-some of them go back as far as May because the statistics for some OECD countries are not available until several months after the events which they record-indicate that Australia's inflation rate, currently standing at 12.3 per cent, is higher than that of Austria, the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Japan, West Germany, Norway, France, Sweden, Canada and Finland. It is very much higher than the OECD average of 8.1 per cent. Our unemployment rate, currently standing at 7.4 per cent, is marginally below the OECD average. But it is still very much above-in fact it is more than double-the latest recorded unemployment rate for Austria which stood at 3.2 per cent, for Japan at 2.4 per cent, for Sweden at 3.1 per cent and for Norway at 2.5 per cent. The objective record shows that our position relative to the rest of the OECD is poor at this stage and that our record through the whole second half of the 1970s was poor compared with the OECD as a whole and dismal compared with that of the OECD leaders.

Despite what the Prime Minister said in 1975, that external influences had absolutely nothing to do with what happened to the Australian economy, or what he says in 1982, that Australia is the passive victim of external forces over which it has no control, neither of those statements is true. The truth is that external influences do have some effect on the Australian economy. It is inevitable, given the magnitude of the world-wide recession, that some disadvantages would be imposed on Australia. But there are two very important factors. The Australian economy has been in a state of permanent recession relative to the rest of the industrialised world for all but one year since 1975 . In only one of the seven years that this Government has been in power has the Australian economy not been in recession relative to the rest of the OECD countries. The cumulative effect of that is that we go into a recession with an unemployment level of 6 per cent or 6 1/2 per cent. Then, as the recession bites and as the Government fails to take any compensatory action at all, inevitably that unemployment level will climb to somewhere between 9 per cent and 10 per cent, or maybe even 11 per cent, some time in the calendar year 1983.

Whilst it is correct that some downturn is inevitable, it is very important to note the starting point from which that downturn occurs. If unemployment were to go from 2 per cent to 3 per cent-as occurred in Japan and Austria-nobody would welcome it, but it would not be catastrophic. But in Australia it will go from 6 per cent to 9 per cent, 10 per cent or maybe 11 per cent. That is catastrophic and it is avoidable. It is possible to minimise the degree to which the Australian economy will drift into recession in the current period, and it was possible to have had a more satisfactory starting point at the beginning of the recession than we in fact had. The reason why neither the potential to minimise the present slump nor the potential to do very much better in the late 1970s has not been realised is that, in both cases, mistaken policies were pursued by this Government and it lacked moral authority. The common denominator of all of those countries that have recorded satisfactory economic statistics-a satisfactory level of economic performance measured by the things that everybody regards as important, such as growth rates, unemployment rates and inflation control-is that they have an effective prices and incomes policy, whether it is called that or not. Those countries include the Netherlands, the Scandinavian countries, Japan and Austria.

In Australia, federal governments have very limited coercive power in that area . They have almost no direct coercive power. So it is essential, if a prices and incomes policy is to be successfully implemented, that the national government which seeks to implement it has, and deserves, moral authority. Implicit in the origin of this Government was that it would find it difficult to obtain any moral authority. After seven years in power, it neither has nor deserves any. For example, a government which has presided over massive tax evasion, about which it knew a good deal, both in aggregate and in detail, for five years and did nothing, is in a weak moral position to ask unions, or any group in the community, to restrain their demands on the economic product in the common interest. This Government, for reasons that had nothing to do with moral outrage but everything to do with electoral expediency, allowed billions and billions of dollars of revenue to be lost because income tax was being evaded and avoided.

After the release of the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports the Government forecast its intention to legislate to recover a tiny fraction of the billions of dollars that had been evaded. Even had the Government sought to recover the lot, that would not have exempted it from the lion's share of the responsibility for what happened. It said it would legislate to recover some of that money-a tiny fraction. Since then, as a result of two major waterings down of the legislation originally introduced on 23 September, only a fraction of that tiny fraction will be recovered. The clause 3 (12) amendment inserted in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill when it came back to the House of Representatives on 21 October exempts completely from liability the vendor shareholders of a particular class of company. I will not go into the details of that class of company because it is a terribly complex matter. However, about 700 companies-about one-sixth of the companies originally stated to have been covered by the legislation-have been exempted by that clause. A great deal more than one-sixth of the revenue has been lost because those companies tended to be companies with very much larger current year taxation liabilities.

A particular company in this category is Treamog Ltd, which had a current year untaxed profit at the time it was flogged off of $3 1/2m. That clause 3 (12) amendment will exempt the vendor shareholders of Treamog from the liability to return that $3 1/2m, which I remind the Senate that the Prime Minister described only a couple of months ago as stolen money. That stolen money, thanks to the clause 3 (12) amendment, may now be retained by the people who stole it. The people who stole it-I use the Prime Minister's terminology-are the vendor shareholders of Treamog. I wonder who they are. It has been mentioned before but in case people have forgotten the principal vendor shareholder of Treamog was Denis Horgan, former finance committee chairman of the Western Australian Liberal Party. I charge this Government with inserting clause 3 (12) into the Bill with the conscious and deliberate intention of exempting Denis Horgan and other powerful figures in the Liberal Party from their obligation to return what the Prime Minister had previously designated as stolen money. In other words, if people are rich enough and have positions of power and influence in the Liberal Party they do not have to modify their demands for a share of the economic cake through the market place or the semi-regulated market place. They do not even have to return money which the Prime Minister said was stolen. Providing they are rich enough and influential enough they can make this Government water down the legislation, which it itself had introduced, in a way that will forgo the collection of several hundred millions of dollars of evaded taxation. What moral authority can any government which has done that expect to have or receive?

The former member for Flinders is to retire with a lump sum pension entitlement , 95 per cent of which is tax free, of $470,000. If he were to die-that could happen to all of us at any time-his widow would receive for the rest of her life a pension of $39,000 a year in 1982 value dollars, indexed for life. That will occur even though the pension has already been commuted. What moral authority does a government that presides over that system have when it tells the ordinary working people of Australia to moderate their demands on the economic product? The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) granted himself in 1964 a 4 3/4 per cent government loan to purchase a house in Canberra. Of the principal of the loan, 82 per cent still has not been repaid and the Deputy Prime Minister still has that government loan at an interest rate of 4 3/4 per cent. Ordinary wage earners and working people are paying from 13 per cent to 16 per cent or 17 per cent. What moral authority does a government which presides over that situation have when it asks ordinary working people to modify their demands on the economic product?

This Government, in this Appropriation Bill, filched $1.5m in a one-line appropriation-it was put down in the name of the Department of the Treasury-to run a political advertising campaign for the Liberal Party for the election that the Prime Minister planned to have this year. I understand that the Secretary to the Treasury personally remonstrated with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) over this gross misuse of public money. Indeed, I would be very disappointed in Mr Stone if he failed to do so because whatever policy disagreements people on this side of the House may have with him he has always been regarded as a very proper custodian of public funds. What moral authority can a government that did that expect to have?

I could go through a number of similar items but time does not permit me to do so. I want to make this appeal to the Government: If there is anything to be learnt from the empirical evidence that is available around the world, it is that without a social consensus on a prices and incomes policy the goals which we on this side of the House, and even, I submit, the majority of people on the other side of the House want-the goals of full employment, rates of economic growth high enough to sustain full employment and low rates of unemployment- cannot be achieved unless an effective prices and incomes policy is put in place . An effective prices and incomes policy cannot be put in place, firstly, unless the Government aspires to put one in its place, which so far this Government has not chosen to do, and secondly, unless it has the moral authority to expect to be taken seriously when it asks the ordinary working people of Australia to accept that discipline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with some policy issues which concern a very large proportion of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83. More than $4,000m is to be spent this year by the Department of Defence and the Department of Defence Support. There is a very real danger in the area of defence that we will always be preparing for the last war or the the last war but one and that we will sink into an equipment and policy rut. The recent Falkland Islands campaign provided a unique opportunity to assess the performance of modern maritime weapons. It was in fact the first significant maritime war for nearly 40 years. Of course, it also provided an opportunity to see the performance of other weapons, but these were less important because the various Middle East wars provided much information on the performance of those weapons. I do not want to deal today with any of the moral questions involved in the Falklands dispute or the political questions, such as how the British permitted the Islands to be taken in the first place and what Britain will do now that the Islands have been recaptured. These are fascinating questions but they are irrelevant to the Bill before us and also irrelevant to my purpose, which is to point out the lessons which we can learn and which may affect the future equipment and training of the Australian Defence Force.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I do that I should point out that the Falklands operation was a one-off. It was an amphibious operation carried out at a range of 8,000 miles and without local air superiority. In fact, it was carried out with a 10:1 air inferiority. Although it worked on this occasion I hope that such an operation will never be attempted again-at any rate, not attempted by us. Indeed, when the difficulties of the Falklands operation became clear, particularly with the onset of winter, the only comparable operation I could think of was the attempted invasion of England by the Spanish in 1588. Before the armada sailed a senior Spanish officer, probably the second in command, Vice Admiral de Recalde, felt the operation was impossible, but he said:

. . . it is well known that we fight in God's cause. So . . . God will surely arrange matters . . . by depriving the English of their wits . . . But unless God helps us by a miracle the English . . . will knock us to pieces . . . So we are sailing against England in the confident hope of a miracle.

As it turned out, in the Falklands the Argentinians were deprived of their wits. The British servicemen, with excellent professional skills, were very successful . This is not to denigrate all the Argentinian forces. The Argentine Air Force in particular attacked with commendable courage and continued to attack though suffering very severe losses. In fact, at the end of the campaign it was virtually wiped out as an effective fighting force. Although the precise circumstances of the Falklands operation will not recur one can easily imagine circumstances where we might have to take similar action, though at a shorter range, on a smaller scale and in less unfavourable weather conditions. The capability to mount a small scale amphibious assault at short notice is one which our Defence Force should certainly have. It is an option which must be available to the Government.

What lessons can we learn from the Falklands campaign? The first lesson is the impressive speed with which the British reacted after being initially caught by surprise. Merchant ships were requisitioned and converted, fitted with helicopter platforms, communications and, in some cases, guns. Although it was not done, one would have liked installed launchers to launch chaff to decoy missiles. All this was done very rapidly and with a speed that reflected sound prior planning. The British were lucky that, as part of their North Atlantic Treaty Organisation contingency planning, they had an organisation in readiness to deploy marines in the Arctic Circle in Northern Norway. Much of the equipment and much of the organisation for that part of Britain's strategy was also suitable for use in the South Atlantic in the Falklands. Nevertheless, the prior planning was impressive. I very much doubt whether we are doing any comparable planning.

One point which I am sure will not have escaped logisticians is that one of the crucial shortages of the British was the shortage of tankers. That throws into highlight the fact that the new replenishment ship being built for the Royal Australian Navy is already two years behind schedule. Its failure to be delivered means that there is a serious weakness in our Defence Force. Australia would have a significant amphibious capability if we had an aircraft carrier which also incorporated some troop carrying capacity. We have the HMAS Tobruk, which is similar to the Sir Lancelot class used so successfully in the Falklands , six heavy landing craft and the troop and vehicle carrier HMAS Jervis Bay. What we need is a survey of which Australian flag merchant ships could usefully be requisitioned to support a small scale amphibious operation-say, two battalion strength-and what modifications would be necessary, such as helicopter decks and so on, so that designs could be prepared and materials stockpiled. I regret to say that I am not sure that this has not yet been done.

I was disappointed a few months ago when I suggested that the Department of Defence should look at the proposed over-the-beach supply ship for the Antarctic Division to see what modifications should be incorporated to make it suitable for Navy use in defence emergencies. The lack of interest by the Department of Defence was deafening. We used to have a program whereby all Australian-built merchant ships had incorporated during construction the necessary stiffening for gun mountings and the fittings for degausing equipment and so on. This program has long since gone by the board. We should reinstate one tailored to our modern needs.

The other impressive aspect of the British preliminary moves was the speed with which the initial land force was assembled. The Royal Marines provided three battalions and the Parachute Brigade two battalions within two days. I have pointed out to the Senate before that the Royal Marine Corps, with 11,000 men, has five immediately available battalions, whereas the Australian Army, with 32, 000 men, has only two immediately available battalions-and neither of these is trained in either amphibious or parachute operations. What we need in our Army is more immediately available battalions trained in both airborne and amphibious operations. The Army should drop its nonsense of a regular army division, which imposes immense overheads but has no usable output. There is no way a regular division would ever be committed to battle. Any savings that we can make in our peacetime manpower would be very usefully diverted to capital equipment. After all, it costs about $1m a year to maintain a regular army platoon.

The final point about the preparatory phase of the Falklands campaign is that we shall have to revise our ideas about how long troops can remain on board ship without losing their fighting edge. Conventional wisdom was that four or five days would be the limit, particularly in the bad weather of the South Atlantic in winter and the cramped conditions on board the two aircraft carriers and the other troop carrying vessels. The ships seemed to steam interminably up and down the coast of South America, yet the troops were certainly fighting fit when they landed.

Turning to the actions around the Falklands, I should make it clear once again that this was an extraordinary operation-the only amphibious operation that has ever been attempted, let alone succeeded, without local air superiority. This forced some very dangerous tactical decisions, such as operating destroyers close inshore, where they were very vulnerable to surprise air attack. The destroyers had to be there to defend the landing craft and troop ships, such as the Canberra, as well as providing artillery support for the troops ashore. At least close inshore they were safe from Exocet missiles, which are not effective close inshore as they tend to home in on the land rather than on the ships.

There is no doubt that the Exocet missiles were the sensation of the campaign. They are not unique. They are similar, but with very much lower performance, to the Harpoon missiles with which our ships, submarines and aircraft are equipped. The Harpoon has roughly twice the range of the Exocet. As far as I can determine , about 12 Exocets were launched during that campaign-some from shore and some from aircraft-and three hit, which is a 25 per cent success rate. There is no doubt that the British were seriously underequipped to deal with the Exocets.

There are four areas of defence against such missiles. The first is to shoot down low flying aircraft before they launch their missiles. This requires airborne early warning radar sets, to give warning of the approaching aircraft, and fighters with pulse-doppler radar sets so that low flying aircraft can be distinguished from sea returns. The British had neither. The second area of defence occurs when the missile is launched, when the defending ships need radar and radio intercept sets to give warning. In at least one case, the attack on the destroyer Sheffield, the British warning system failed completely. I hope that our Navy is informed of what happened.

After missile detection the need is for jammers and decoy launchers. Of the three ships hit by Exocets, two-the Sheffield and the Birmingham-did not use their jammers or decoys, and the third, the merchant ship Atlantic Conveyer, did not have any to use. Incidentally, the Atlantic Conveyer was very unlucky. It was on the far side of the force. An Exocet missile, I understand, was neatly decoyed through the force but hit the Atlantic Conveyer on the far side because she had no decoys of her own. But, in general, how well these jammers and decoys worked on the Exocets would require detailed analysis. I hope that this information, too, is available to our Navy.

One thing that comes out of this type of defence-particularly the sinking of the Atlantic Conveyer by accident, on the far side of a task force which has successfully defended itself against the missiles-is the importance of very tight and effective command and control. It requires a ship of the Invincible type to exercise that type of control of the various ship's gun systems, missile decoys and intercept sets.

Finally, if all else fails, the ships can attempt to shoot down the missiles with close range guns or missiles which, to be effective, have to be automated. The British were poorly equipped in this area. They had only two destroyers with close range anti-missile missile systems, and these two were tagging the two carriers, the Hermes and the Invincible, providing them with some anti-missile defence which they did not have. This was a clear weakness in the force. As I said at the outset, it was seriously underequipped to deal with this threat. The British Navy has been designed to operate in the North Atlantic in a NATO environment, and it assumes in various ways that the necessary equipment will be provided by others. Its limitation was revealed when it had to work on its own.

Our Navy, too, might have to work on its own. How well would we cope in circumstances such as those of the Falklands? We have no airborne early warning capability. This is an urgent need. The suggestion that this should be provided by shore based aircraft is a dangerous delusion. The airborne early warning component of the task force must be integral with the force. With the way things are going, it will have to be helicopter-borne. After the Falklands crisis, the British have now developed-I think it must be only a lash-up job-airborne early warning equipment to go in one of their Sea King helicopters. This is a line of development that we must encourage and acquire for our own forces. One of these airborne early warning helicopters is now operating in the South Atlantic on the Illustrious. I am sure that after their experience the British will be giving high priority to such a development. They fell into the trap-and they have learnt a hell of a lesson from it-of thinking that shore based aircraft would provide this. That is a trap into which wise naval forces never fall.

In looking at our capabilities I wish to point out that without an aircraft carrier we have no fighter defence. That is a crucial weakness. Again, one cannot effectively defend a naval task force at sea with shore based aircraft. It has never been effectively done. It does not work. What happens is that they have other priorities, or one is at sea in fine weather and their airfields are fog-bound, as happened in the recent exercise operating out of Williamtown in Australia. If air power is integral to the survival of the task force, it must be there; it cannot be based somewhere else, because it will not be there when one needs it.

The third weakness of our force is not strictly a weakness. We have the necessary electronic equipment, intercept sets, jammers and decoy launchers, but obviously we shall have to re-evaluate them in the light of the practical experience that has been learnt from comparable equipment. At present we lack any ship capable of providing co-ordination and control for the defence of a task force against missile attack. That is the role of a fully equipped ship, such as the Invincible. The Melbourne could partially do it; but we need a command and control ship to co-ordinate this type of defence. Without that, the fleet is a collection of individual ships.

With regard to the last ditch defence, the decision to fit the Phalanx in our four FFGs, our new frigates, is very welcome. But ships such as our three DDGs will remain very vulnerable. We should look very closely at fitting the lightweight Sea Wolf anti-missile system which the British deployed in the Falklands.

The whole campaign emphasised the flexibility and value of the aircraft carriers, which can carry up to a battalion of troops each, with helicopters for troop carrying, anti-submarine work and as Exocet decoys, and fixed wing aircraft for fighter defence, reconnaissance, surface strikes and ground force support. It is interesting that in the latter stages of the campaign some of the Royal Air Force Harriers operating from the carriers were based ashore on an extemporised air strip and provided very close and immediate support for the Army. That is the sort of support which they alone can provide.

Of course, there is a limit to what two small aircraft carriers can provide with negligible shore based support. In particular, the 20 Sea Harriers were ludicrously overworked. What they were trying to provide was fighter defence, ground force support, reconnaissance-there were no AEW aircraft-and surface strike. There is no way 20 aircraft could possibly have done that. Nevertheless, they performed very well. One of the more glaring weaknesses of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the new aircraft carrier for the Australian Defence Force was its absurd assessment of the capability of the Harrier. I am glad that my colleague Senator Collard dealt with that. I shall not deal with it again. The Committee's ignorance was profound. As I said at the time, I thought that it was an inappropriate reference to give to such a body. I think that careful reading of the report would thoroughly justify that remark. The Committee's strategic assessment was very old fashioned. It was rather like the strategic assessment of King Ethelred the Unready. Its knowledge of the equipments concerned was derisory. I do not think any great notice should be taken of its report.

Nevertheless it has made remarks about the capability of the Harrier which, as I said, Senator Collard has dealt with. The Harriers did perform well. They had a 30:0 success rate against the Argentine aircraft, including a high proportion of Mirages. I do not think one should get too carried away with the Harriers' air superiority role. They were operating essentially at low level. The heavy missile defence of a modern fleet makes a high level attack by aircraft very unattractive. They tend to come in low and at low levels the capabilities of the Harrier are very relevant and very competitive with aircraft such as the Mirage, particularly when the Mirages are, as they were on this occasion, operating at long range. The reason I said one should not get too carried away is that the Harriers had a markedly superior missile capability. They were using modern sidewinders. The Argentinian Mirages were using old-fashioned French Matra missiles, semi-active homing, which the Sea Harriers had little difficulty in avoiding. Nevertheless even if the Argentinian Mirages had had comparable missiles I think the Sea Harriers would have out-performed the Mirages because of their manoeuvreability and their smaller infra-red signature. Their ability to master infra-red signature would have made them very formidable opponents for the Mirages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the competency of the respective crews relevant?

—Yes, I think it is. It is very hard to judge without an analysis. I do not know whether the Argentinians would yet be prepared to co-operate in such an analysis to compare efficiency. I think one can say that of the three Argentinian services, the Air Force came out much the best. It attacked with very great courage and a fair degree of competence. What it was like in air-to- air combat I really cannot assess. That would require a lot of analysis. It is rather difficult to assess because of the marked inferiority of the British missiles, but there were some remarkable performances by British pilots in that campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting point was made that both the Royal Naval and the RAF Harriers operated from the two carriers, the HMS Hermes and the HMS Invincible. I am told that the pilots much preferred the Hermes because it was designed as a carrier and had a very much larger flight deck. I think everyone knows that the Invincible was not really designed as an aircraft carrier and the pilots found the flight deck rather restrictive. But the fact that the RAF pilots-many of them without previous carrier experience-could operate in such weather from a carrier shows the incredible capability of the Harrier. In fact a number of RAF Harriers flew from England, refuelling on the way with one stop at the Ascension Islands and then made their first ever deck landing at sea off the Falklands. That is a capability we would never have contemplated with any other aircraft but the Harrier. The flexibility the Harrier provides, the ability to operate afloat or ashore, raises the question whether when we get the Harrier types-as I am sure we will-they should not all be manned by the Air Force.
