The reconnaissance by the RAF Nimrods operating from the Ascension Islands, 4, 000 miles away, was obviously inadequate, as evidenced by a large merchant ship reaching Port Stanley undetected in the very late stages of the campaign. There are no real lessons here for us for I am sure we would never contemplate such an operation, 4,000 miles from our nearest base. Nevertheless, one can easily imagine circumstances under which we might conduct operations at a substantial distance from our nearest base and to ensure that our forces are never left without land-based air support we have an obvious need for an in-flight refuelling capability. That is why the announcement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) that we are to acquire two 707s to provide us with this capability is so welcome. I hope that when we get them they will be compatible with those of our American allies. One of the peculiar features of the Falklands campaign was the fact that British aircraft could not refuel from American tankers, despite their being North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies.

Before I leave the aircraft carrier question I make two further points. The first is that much has been made of the use of container ships such as the Atlantic Conveyor as parking lots for extra Harriers. I think the total force at one stage was as high as 35-twenty in the two aircraft carriers and 15 more in the parking lots. This is obviously a good way of deploying more Harriers than could possibly be physically fitted in the two aircraft carriers. But these container ships were not actually operating the Harriers. To do that they would have needed servicing facilities, fuel, ammunition and appropriate radar and radio. To put all this into a ship would result in a valuable unit which would justify internal protection and defensive armament, and before long one would have gained an aircraft carrier. A container ship can be a useful supplement to an aircraft carrier but the aircraft carrier itself is still needed.

The other point I want to make about aircraft carriers is their high survivability. For some reason the totally false impression has been created that aircraft carriers are particularly vulnerable. The facts disprove this. Before the Second World War it was an article of faith among shore-based air power advocates that no aircraft carrier could possibly survive within range of a shore-based bombing attack. Yet in six years of World War II more than 200 aircraft carriers were operated by both sides and the number sunk by shore-based air attack was one. Of course during that use the aircraft carriers were taking on and subduing shore-based air forces and the number sunk by shore-based air attack was one. Since World War II aircraft carriers have provided the major part of the tactical air support in successive campaigns, such as Korea, Suez, Vietnam and now the Falklands, and no aircraft carrier has been sunk or even damaged. No ship is unsinkable, but aircraft carriers do have a remarkable capacity to survive.

Some other points must be made briefly. The British nuclear powered submarines completely cowed the Argentine navy, particularly after the sinking of the General Belgrano. After that, as far as one can gather, the Argentine Navy remained in its territorial waters. The Argentine submarines-two new German- built ones and two old American-built ones-one of which was sunk, achieved nothing. They did force on the British considerable measures of precautionary defence against them but I have not been able to find out whether they actually tried to attack. Attacking in those sorts of conditions with heavy, deep swell requires a degree of submarine training which I doubt they had.

Another point is that the neutralising of the airfield at Port Stanley proved a difficult task. In three strikes by Vulcan heavy bombers a total of one crater was made in the runway; and C130 Hercules aircraft used the runway till the very end. Quite apart from the obvious political difficulties of attacking the mainland Argentine airfields, it may be that the reason they did not do so was that they could not guarantee that their attacks would be effective. The Harriers could not contribute much to to this for two reasons. One is that they had no self-penetrating bombs with which to crater runways. If a 1,000 pound bomb were dropped from a very low altitude it would make a very small crater. Secondly, the Argentine air defences at Port Stanley were much heavier than the British had been led to expect and the Harriers had to attack from very low level. As I said, the Harriers finished up operating ashore from extemporised runways.

Perhaps the most decisive advantage the British troops had over the Argentine Army was in night fighting. This was partly a matter of training and partly a matter of equipment, particularly infra-red equipment. I am sure there will be some equipment and training lessons for our Army when the Falklands lessons are fully analysed. I do not want to make much of this because there has been a great deal of experience of these aspects in the various Middle East wars.

Finally, there is the matter of the loss of so many Royal Navy ships through fire. I must say I was not surprised. For years it has been making its ships more and more like tinder-boxes. It is not a question of the aluminium superstructure. Aluminium does not burn; it does melt at about 800* Fahrenheit as opposed to 1500* Fahrenheit for steel. But it is certainly inconvenient to have the superstructure melting around the crew. For the superstructure to melt there must be a fire underneath it. That should be what one aims to prevent. Incidentally, the most spectacular loss through fire, HMS Sheffield, was a type 42 destroyer with a steel, not aluminium, superstructure. Again, the Exocet missile did not even go off. The Sheffield was lost through the fire caused by the unburnt propellant in the missile. The Royal Navy has never been very good at fire precautions. Even during World War II many ships were lost unnecessarily through fire. I well remember my shock when I joined the cruiser HMAS Australia in the Pacific in the Second World War. At that stage I had seen only British fire precautions. I was shattered when I went on board that ship. She had been stripped. There was nothing that would burn. She was later hit by six suicide aircraft which is roughly the effective power of an Exocet. She did not burn. There was nothing to burn. We, perhaps, had been converted with the power of the new converts, but at least it was an example of what could be done.

Since World Was II, the Royal Navy's fire precautions have deteriorated still further. I regret to say that our Navy has followed suit with the British designed ships. They have wooden furniture, carpets, curtains, linoleum, plastic panels, plastic covers and so on. They have inflammable bedding. Our United States-built ships are markedly superior in fire precautions. The Navy must urgently bring all our ships up to the standard of our United States-built ones and see whether we should go further. We must have ships that are not fire traps . Honourable senators may notice that I have not mentioned the British Government welshing on the sale of HMS Invincible. This will probably cost us about $500m. Although the Invincible performed excellently in the Falklands, there was nothing in her performance that was not clearly predictable and known to the British Government before it agreed to the sale. Nothing was changed by the campaign. The reason I will not say anything about the British Government's behaviour is that anything I did say would be unprintable.

The final thing we must learn from the Falklands is the unpredictable nature of wars. Britain was surprised by the trouble in the Falklands. We cannot be sure that we will not be similarly surprised. We must be certain that our Defence Force is prepared and capable of reacting appropriately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity presented by the debate on the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 to make some references to the quality of administration in the Attorney-General's Department as revealed by the Estimates Committee hearings and some more recent events. In case anyone in the Senate fears that this is an opportunity that I will take on numerous further occasions when we get to the Committee stage of this Bill and the consideration of the Attorney-General's Department in particular I make the point that I will not be available for that Committee stage debate and am taking the present opportunity to do what I would otherwise do then. It is perhaps a little unsporting of me to pursue the question of the Attorney-General's Department's performance in the continued absence, through illness, of the Attorney-General, Senator Durack. But the scale and magnitude of the maladministration, the delay, the neglect, the incompetence and the lethargy demonstrated by that Department and made evident particularly during the recent round of Estimates Committee hearings demands that these questions be aired once again, although I will not take the time of the Senate to do so at the length which might be thought appropriate if justice were really to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The Estimates Committee hearings revealed, of course, a lot of the detail to which Mr Costigan had made fairly broad reference in his report about the performance of the Attorney-General's Department in relation to the pursuit of bottom-of-the-harbour tax avoiders and the enactment of remedial legislation in that area. A number of points were confirmed by those hearings. First, no coherent or thought out advice was given to the Australian Taxation Office at any stage-certainly not in the crucial period of 1977 to 1978-as to the availability of the existing law to deal with these measures or as to the kind of litigation strategy which might be advanced to stop this sort of activity stone dead. No such coherent or thought out advice was given, despite numerous requests for such advice and for action received by the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department from the Australian Taxation Office. When that advice was finally forthcoming, firstly in oral form in 1978 and subsequently in written form in 1979, it has become quite clear from the evidence that has been made available to the Senate and otherwise put on the public record that there was no clear, detailed, thorough or careful analysis at any stage of the law upon which that advice was given. That state of affairs will, I suggest, become even more clearly revealed when the Government finally produces, as it must, the further documents in this matter which have been the subject of a resolution from the Senate and which are presently awaiting the finalisation of some appropriate filtering procedure to enable the substance of those documents to be revealed without, at the same time, doing anything which could put at risk prosecutions in this area. I say no more about that because, undoubtedly, that will be the subject of further debate in the Senate.

A further matter that has become evident from the Estimates Committee hearings is that there was no appreciation by senior officers within the Attorney-General 's Department at any stage of the extraordinarily important test case character of the proposed action in Perth against the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme that was, in fact, discovered very early in the course of events by the Taxation Office and in respect of which an early decision was taken in 1975 to pursue a prosecution. The Estimates Committee hearing revealed a dogged insistence on the part of senior officers of the Attorney-General's Department, right up to the top to Mr Neaves, the Secretary, that that kind of litigation taken at that time would not have been so significant and might even have been counter-productive. There was an utter failure to acknowledge the utility of the deterrent effect of effective, swift action demonstrating a government will to act at the appropriate time.

A further thing about the conduct of the Attorney-General's Department in relation to this extraordinarily important tax avoidance and evasion matter was the revelation that, again, has emerged over the last few weeks, that the Attorney-General's Department spent nearly three years between 1978 and 1980 fooling around aimlessly in drafting what eventually became the 1980 Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act. It fooled around in the sense that no serious consideration appears to have been given by anybody at any stage to the necessity for that legislation and the precise condition of the existing law and the inadequacies of that law making such legislation necessary. Apparently, some consideration was given, we were told during the Estimates Committee hearings, to the adequacy of existing law at a meeting between Senator Durack, Mr O' Donovan and Mr Neaves at some point during this period. But no one is able to tell us what precisely the date of that meeting was, and what precisely was discussed. So one is unable to have much confidence about the quality of the thoughtfulness that went into this aspect of the Attorney-General's Department's administration.

Finally, of course, in relation to this whole unhappy saga, it has been revealed in recent weeks in the course of this debate that there has been no proper or effective supervision at a central level of the performance of the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department. The bizarre, festering mess of the Perth Office of the DCS is simply the most obvious manifestation of that lack of supervision. It is one thing, one might think, to have a relatively relaxed work environment in the Attorney-General's Department as anywhere else. It seems to me to be quite another thing to have someone with a responsibility for running taxation prosecutions running on the side a little agency in company matters for Brian Maher, the nation's most notorious tax avoidance and evasion promoter, and, just for good measure, a squalid little escort agency involving most of the female members, it seems, of the family of the officer concerned. The behaviour of the officer in question at the Perth DCS office, which was revealed in the Costigan report, has become something of a national joke. But it is a joke which leaves a rather sour taste in one's mouth when one contemplates the significance of this behaviour in terms of the quality of government administration in a crucially important area. What was revealed, moreover-I keep coming back to the Estimates Committee hearings into this matter -is that notwithstanding the manifest inadequacy of the performance of the Crown Solicitor's Division and the State Deputy Crown Solicitor's officers, an inadequacy that had at least been recognised by the Department to the extent of setting in train a joint management review some little time ago, nonetheless, there was still an extraordinary failure of expedition by the Department in implementing the sound and sensible recommendations of that joint management review. We had revealed to us, again in the Estimates Committee hearings, that a program of implementation, intended to last some two years, a time table that was accepted by the senior officers of the Department as sensible and appropriate, has already stretched out to something like four years, with no end in sight as to when that particular series of administrative changes will be accomplished.

No doubt, as was made clear both in the joint management review and in other people's evidence, a good deal of the problem so far as the maladministration in the Crown Solicitor's Division is concerned has had traditionally to do with the extraordinarily heavy work load that has been borne by the Crown Solicitor himself. I would not wish to sound utterly unsympathetic to the individuals concerned who have occupied those positions because I know well just how debilitating an effect that kind of work load must have had on their capacity simultaneously to administer a very complex and extensive administration operation. But the point remains that there have been spectacular failures of administration by successive Crown solicitors-perhaps for good reason-and they have been failures of administration brought about by the utter inability of those with decision making power to appreciate the necessity for a much more expanded administrative apparatus in this area and the utilisation or the application of many more resources to make the system work. Of course there are competent and dedicated officers at all levels still working within the Attorney -General's Department. But there has been, in recent years, and certainly in recent months, a total collapse of morale in that Department. The revelations to which I have referred are not the cause of that collapse of morale but simply a symptom of what has been a very long-standing decay.

Since the Estimates Committee hearings were completed further revelations still have come tumbling out about the quality of administration in this law enforcement area within the Attorney-General's Department. The Crown Solicitor's Division clearly continues to be something of a tumultuous area with there now being three Deputy Crown Solicitor's positions more or less simultaneously being advertised in the nation's Press, one of them becoming vacant in Perth as a result of the disciplinary action against Mr Massey, another one becoming vacant in Sydney through the departure, in somewhat exceptional circumstances, it appears, of the head of the Sydney office, and now, it seems, we have the impending retirement of the head of the Melbourne office, creating yet another vacancy.

While all this has been happening we have had the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, in its medifraud inquiry, drawing out, bit by bit-it will be fascinating to see the final report-the long history of incompetence and maladministration, again by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department, in pursuit of medifraud prosecutions, a failure of action by the Department of Health and the Attorney-General's Department between them which seems to have cost the nation something like $100m a year. Then we have had the quite justified criticism continuing to be levied against the Crown Solicitor's Division of the Attorney-General's Department in relation to its total lack of performance so far as trade practices prosecutions are concerned. I have made reference to this in the Parliament before and I simply now refer to the long article in the Australian Financial Review by Paul Malone on 1 November 1982 which documents the long and abominable series of demonstrations of incapacity by the various Deputy Crown Solicitor's Offices in those trade practices prosecution areas.

What has been the response of the Acting Attorney-General and the Attorney- General's Department to all of this? On the one hand we have had a series of disciplinary forays being mounted, confined, however, to just three officers in the Perth Crown Solicitor's Office against whom two sets of charges have so far been determined, with adverse findings being made, and with one other set of charges, I understand, still outstanding. The point to be made about that, of course, is that for all the utility of such charges-I do not in any way seek to understate the desirability of maladministration being dealt with in this way- these are still essentially the low men on the totem pole within the Attorney- General's Department. It is very obvious that no action has been taken against the rather more senior members of that department, extending all the way up to the top, whose negligence and administrative ineffectiveness can be argued to have been at least as damaging as anything that was accomplished by the Masseys, the Bercoves and the O'Sullivans of this world.

The second response is a rather fascinating one, as it appears. That has been the flurry of activity by the Government and the Department in recent weeks designed to bring about, as it appears from Press reports, an ultimate split in the Attorney-General's Department so that it will operate in the future not just as the Attorney-General's Department but as a Department of Justice as well. It seems that the proposed Department of Justice would contain the Justice Division of the Attorney-General's Department, that is, the policy division, the Deputy Crown Solicitor's division, the proposed National Crimes Commission and the recently established office of the Special Prosecutor, leaving the Attorney- General's Department to deal with all the rest of the policy areas which are presently within its jurisdiction.

I find it rather fascinating to see the way in which there has been a scurrying by the Minister and the senior departmental officials off to the bottom drawer to dust off, for further contemporary scrutiny, a proposal that has been around, in one form or another, for decades. The motivation for this particular exercise is pretty obvious. It is to divert attention from what has been demonstrated to be spectacular incompetence in the administration of the Attorney-General's Department, to pretend that the reason for it is some fundamental structural problem and to pretend that that structural problem can be solved simply by cloning the Attorney-General's Department, producing out of the one department two more or less identical bodies doing the same sort of thing as the Attorney- General's Department always has done but doing it through the agency of two separate departments rather than one.

It may be that there is a need for some structural changes in this area. I indeed have floated one of them-the idea that the Crown Solicitor's Division be replaced by a semi-independent director of public prosecutions on the United Kingdom basis. But I certainly, and the Opposition, I believe, would need a lot of convincing before we believed that this particular exercise has any other rational justification than a cosmetic one. I would need a great deal of persuading that the proposed Department of Justice, with the proposed division of functions, is anything more than an attempt to divert attention from what has been a failure by a number of individuals, starting with the Minister, of course , but extending down through the senior levels of the Department, to perform up to scratch. It is failure that has had very debilitating and unhappy consequences for the nation as a whole and it is a failure that I doubt can be corrected by other than fairly drastic replacement of the individuals concerned. Simple reorganisation of the kind that is proposed is unlikely to make very much difference.

The remaining things I want to say are directed to the law reform area in which the Attorney-General and his Department have indeed built up a lamentable record over the last few years. This is something which I have had constant cause to attack. I do not repeat on this occasion the things that I have said on innumerable others, not least during discussion of a matter of public importance on 8 September 1982. At that time I drew attention to and fully documented something like 32 instances of serious delay or maladministration-a good many of those involving utter failure or unwillingness to act in key law reform areas. But I make the point-I think this is the occasion when it is appropriate to make it-that that failure continues on the part of the Attorney-General's Department.

At Question Time today I raised a question with Senator Chaney about the failure of the Government to implement the concept of an Australian sentencing council, the central recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission in its 636-page report on the sentencing of Federal offenders that it brought down in January 1980. Senator Chaney's answer, in which he justified the Government's failure to act by reference to a rather glib remark that most criminals in this country are prosecuted under State rather than Federal law, demonstrates either a profound ignorance or a profound indifference, or both, to the fact that the Law Reform Commission had in fact devoted an enormous amount of its resources over a long period in dealing with just that question of Federal offenders, and sentencing law and practice in relation to them. The cavalier dismissal of these sorts of initiatives and this sort of work, based as it is on public hearings and the gathering of a great deal of evidence, does not say much for the Government's sensitivity in the law reform area.

The particular law reform issue to which I want to draw attention finally in my remarks goes to the question of family law, where the performance of this Government has been nothing short of disgraceful. After long consideration by parliamentary committees and other bodies we had the introduction, now over a year ago, of a Family Law Amendment Bill, not designed to do anything terribly drastic so far as reshaping family law in this country but certainly designed to work a number of improvements in the way in which that law was actually operating. The situation is that, although that Bill has been sitting around for over a year now, and although the Senate will be sitting another three weeks and the House of Representatives will be sitting another two weeks in toto, I understand that that Bill will not be brought on this year. The result is that literally thousands of people who are being inconvenienced or whose rights are being put at risk by the failure of the present Act to be effective procedurally and in other ways-people who are suffering as a result of the failure of this legislation to get parliamentary air time-will go on suffering, it seems, until at least the middle of next year.

Wives whose husbands receive superannuation benefits some time after the divorce is complete but who receive no share whatsoever in that benefit will go on being disadvantaged by the failure of this legislation to come to pass. Questions about the custody of adopted children will still be determined in the rather inadequately equipped Supreme Court, jurisdiction in these matters being denied to the Family Court. The situation will continue where the Family Court is not able or obliged to take into account in custody matters the wishes of children under 14 years of age-another reform proposed to be accomplished by this legislation. Matrimonial property orders will not be able to be varied where financial circumstances have changed significantly, even where the parties agree and where the welfare of the child requires it, because the provisions of the Act at the moment are inflexible in this respect. Persons other than the parents of a child will go on being prevented from bringing proceedings for custody or guardianship even where the welfare of the child requires it because of the failure of the existing law to be changed in simple ways by this essentially simple piece of legislation. There is no conception of urgency. There is no willingness to deal with these problems. There is endless buck passing and endless throwing away of the sense of urgency that is needed to get these changes into law.

I have one remaining point which goes to matrimonial property questions which have been very much left in the air, left in abeyance, as a result again of the negligence, the maladministration and the failure of this Government to act. There has been a long-standing concern-it is evidenced partially by the superannuation question contained in this Bill-about the inadequacy of existing matrimonial property law to reflect accurately, fairly and equitably the different interest of parties to a marriage. I simply put on the record this matter because I am profoundly disturbed by it. In October 1981 the Attorney- General announced that a committee of inquiry would be appointed to examine matrimonial property law. I have now been informed that the projected starting date of January 1983, already deplorably belated as that date obviously is, is almost certain to be deferred again. The reason for that further delay is the breakdown on negotiations-negotiations which have already gone on for an unbelievable 15 months-for the appointment of a particular gentleman, Professor David Hambly, to head that committee of inquiry. What has happened is that Professor Hambly, who is regarded as one of the nation's experts on family law and family property law in particular, has resigned the deanship in the faculty of law at the Australian National University in anticipation of this appointment -anticipation that he was reasonably entitled to have. He has been inconvenienced in a series of other ways by virtue of rearranging his affairs in order to ready himself to take on this extremely important job. Through the intervention of the Acting Attorney-General, Mr Brown, there was a hasty and abortive attempt to appoint someone other than Professor Hambly. It now appears that Mr Brown has withdrawn from the fray and left it to Senator Durack to sort out the matter. Of course Senator Durrack's reputation for speed in these matters is quite legendary.

I simply make the point that there has been an endless amount of maladministration, of failure to implement through simple administrative decisions-not even serious policy decisions-important reform initiatives which are of real relevance to an enormous number of people in this country. Just as with the matrimonial property law inquiry, just as with the amendments to the Family Law Act, just as with the sentencing council matter, just as with some two dozen other failure of law reform initiatives to which I have referred on previous occasions, the Attorney-General's Department once again has demonstrated itself to be wholly incompetent at doing the job that it has so long been established to do. It is a great pity that so much criticism has had to be directed against the Attorney-General's Department in recent months but I suggest it is an even greater pity that that criticism, extensive and intensive as it has been, so far seems to have failed to bring about any discernible reaction or any discernible improvement on the part of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83, which Bill appropriates a sum of nearly $12 billion. That is a very large sum of money-larger than it was last year. My concern is at the very high cost of government today. It is important to realise that government does not generate money in any way. The powerhouse that generates it is the private sector, and the cost of government in Australia today is astronomical. This is far more than an academic point. This country has to survive in a very competitive international commercial world. Quite simply, we cannot be in business in the 1990s with the techniques that we use at present . Our problems come from three broad sections: Our industrial relations are bad, our tariff policies are bad, and our management practices are bad.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, with trade union relations we cannot tolerate a monopoly of the supply of labour from which we suffer to a degree that no other country does. We have done everything we can, through the Trade Practices Commission, the monopolies commission and all those sorts of things to control the monopoly of capital. People cannot abuse the possession of capital. They certainly cannot use a monopoly position to the detriment of society. Yet we all live under the intolerable imposition of a monopoly of labour coming through the trade union movement. What we have to do to reform the industrial relations situation in this country is to create a market in labour the way that we create a market in capital. That means the abolition of compulsory unionism. It means the abolition of some of the underpinnings for it in the form of minimal wages and such things . The only way to get young people employed is to make the employment of those young people commercially attractive.

The tariff problem is as large as the union relations problem. In brief, what is happening with the excessive levels of tariffs in Australia is that we drive scarce capital resources and other scarce resources into fields that are not productive from a point of view of international competition. It is rather sad that now we are in a very difficult economic time people are saying, 'Let's have higher tariff barriers, let's have higher quotas.' That will not help us one little bit. It might put off dying today until tomorrow but surely as God made little apples we will die tomorrow if we do not reform our inaccurate and inappropriate tariff policies.

The third aspect is that of management. In Australian private industry management there is much that is bad, but I want to talk today about what is bad with respect to government management. Government in Australia is now big business. It is huge business. As I have said, the cost of that government must be met by private industry. Some 35 per cent of gross domestic product is spent by the Federal Government. That is a huge increase compared with the proportion taken historically, just 10 or 20 years ago, by the Federal Government. I do not have a figure as to total government expenditure in Australia but I imagine it amounts to 38 to 40 per cent of GDP. All that money has to be raised in the form of taxes and levies. Not only has that money to be taken out of the community, but we must look also at the cost of the administration that the Government imposes on the community and the efficiency or the inefficiency with which that administration is carried out.

We have all seen the size of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is several inches thick. It has reached the stage where it is beyond reasonable comprehension. If there is one thing this country needs it is to throw out the Income Tax Assessment Act and bring in a simpler form of taxation. I have never seen a figure given by the Treasury Department of what it costs to administer the income tax legislation, but I could believe it would be well over 50 per cent of revenue. It must be a huge expenditure. Just the other day I saw that another large number of assessors was being put on. We just keep on going down the path of patching up an unworkable system, absolutely blind to the quite artificial distortions being created in the economy. We are perverting the goals that we are trying to attain absolutely blind to the huge cost of operating a totally inefficient and unworkable system. Quite simply, we cannot in the commercial world go into the 1990s with the techniques we have at present.

The power that big government exercises through its Public Service in the business field particularly, is enormous. The intelligence, integrity and ability of the Public Service is not in dispute here. The point is that we are asking public servants in so many departments to operate in a commercial field, to exercise a commercial judgment which they simply do not have. Their training is not in that field. We also do not have a system of reward and censure applying to public servants who operate in commercial fields. That is absolutely essential. People must be rewarded when they do well and censured when they make mistakes. It is very hard to see how that can be introduced in the Public Service. Of course, the short answer is that it should not be doing that. Such operations should be left to private industry.

Another matter in regard to the growth of government is of concern to anyone who is interested in democracy in this country. I refer to the sheer size of the Public Service itself. We had a very good example of this a couple of weeks ago when one of the spokesmen for the Public Service in South Australia blatantly campaigned for the Labor Government in the election campaign that was proceeding there. We have reached an intolerable situation, if employees can campaign and use their large numbers against the government of the day. I think that when the more intelligent members of even the Labor Party reflect on that they will become a little uneasy about its possible long term effects.

I would like to instance two or three aspects of the Appropriation Bill in respect of which I believe that waste or lack of control is occurring. The first relates to the estimates for the Department of Aviation. It is just a small point which concerns the Independent Air Fares Committee. That Committee was set up as a consequence of the Airlines Agreement Bill that was approved by the Parliament in March of last year. Basically it was set up to look at how fares were structured in Australia and to come up with a fairer formula. That is a perfectly laudable goal. I forget how many people are on the Committee-it may be four or five-but one would not have thought that its deliberations would occupy more than half a day a month, or a day a month; that they could be conducted at moderate cost. But one finds that the estimates for the Department of Aviation this year provide for an expenditure of $495,000-for four or five people to set the air fares for the Australian travelling public. That is manifestly absurd. We are paying to these people $283,000 in salaries and allowances, and are supporting them at an administrative cost of $212,000. That is absolutely indefensible. It represents an expenditure of $500,000, which one can guarantee in the Estimates for next year will have increased by 25 or 40 per cent-just to set fares. Maybe the setting of fares could be left to the private sector and the market place.

The second department to which I want to refer is the Department of Defence. I do not wish to take as long as did Senator Hamer. I have really been provoked into this by some of the interesting points that he raised. One of the points I would like to make is that the Government has called for a new strategic assessment which will be due in the new year, certainly within the first six months of 1982. The strategic assessment is a confidential document but it is one which identifies the threats to Australia. On it is based the whole of Australia's defence strategy, equipment, Force structure and so on. Everything flows from the strategic assessment. I do not know how often strategic assessments are made. I have never seen one and do not expect to because it is quite a confidential document, but I presume it is made every five or 10 years. In the light of this absolutely crucial assessment being made, it is wrong for the Cabinet to be calling for a decision by 30 November on a major piece of equipment, such as whether or not we need a carrier, and for the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) to be saying that a decision will be made by 30 December. Whatever that decision might be it is irrelevant. The point is that until an assessment of needs is made it is absolutely wrong to be committing oneself one way or the other. The assessment will be made in the new year, presumably a month or two after the Cabinet decides on the carrier.

Senator Hamer had quite a bit to say about the carrier. I would like to take a broader view, first of all, and just look at the situation with respect to the Royal Australian Navy because there is an increasingly vocal concern about Navy purchases over the last 10 years or so. Most have been very unhappy events. There is considerable disquiet about the suitability of the FFG design from a functional point of view. It was designed to meet the low threat case. The high threat case was the Spruance design for the United States Navy. Where the FFGs fit into the Australian fleet structure is rather hard to determine because, from a fighting point of view, they are not terribly well able to look after themselves unaided. Also, there has been a lot of criticism about both the single screw design and quality control generally. The need for a $500,000 repair to Canberra which has become evident in the last couple of weeks highlights what I am talking about.

Another area of concern about the Navy is the provision of helicopters, which are absolutely vital for the FFGs. They were a design requirement, yet the Royal Australian Navy has messed around for years calling tenders for the supply of helicopters that did not exist. The helicopters simply could not be designed because of the lack of the technology that the Navy wanted in them. Fortunately, in the last six months the penny has dropped and the Navy is now assessing what the state of the art is in the world and is proceeding, somewhat belatedly, to write specifications for helicopters that actually can be built and can be bought.

Another area of concern is the Fremantle class ship. I will neglect the mess-up about the main armament on that ship. Tenders were called for the construction of the ship on the basis that detailed design drawings would be available. A contractor was appointed and then it was found that there were no detailed design drawings. That has occasioned the contractor a very considerable cost which has run into millions of dollars. That was a bad administrative mistake on the part of the Navy. We have had problems with HMAS Cook. No one knows how long it will take for Cook to be finished. The ship overran both its contract price and its contract time by a very large margin. The ship received notoriety because the Navy wanted to add extra equipment to it and a big hole was cut in its side later on. My advice is that it is back at the Williamstown Dockyard with major problems with its propulsion and no one knows when it will go into service.

The fleet replenishment ship that is being built at the Cockatoo Island Dockyard poses another problem. I can well remember the Minister giving us cast- iron assurances that the ship would be built at tender price and on time. We are well past the time when the ship should have been finished. No one knows when it will be finished or what it will cost. A large part of that is due to the Navy itself.

It is true that the contractor, Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd, was very keen to get that contract and bent over backwards to get it. The company may have overcommitted itself, but well over 200 design changes have been requested by the Navy at very short notice which have added enormously to the cost and to the delay of the ship. I am told that one of the most recent changes is a requirement that the forklift trucks for moving stores be doubled in weight and carrying capacity which means that the deck plates have to be doubled up and the deck beams have to be doubled up underneath them. The builder has given up in despair; he does not know where to go. About the only thing the Navy has done well recently from a purchasing point of view concerns the submarine program and the submarine weapons update, which technically, functionally, and in every operational way, has been a brilliantly successful venture and a venture which has been of great value to Australia's deterrent capacity.

I do not wish to spend much time going down the path that Senator Hamer went down, but I wish to comment on a few of the comments he made because there are other points of view on this matter. One of the great lessons of the Falkland Islands war was that the traditional and time honoured Navy technique of operating a blockade was successful and worked well. The British submarines blockaded, or were thought by the Argentinians to have blockaded, the harbour. This bottled up the Argentine Navy and thereby kept the British supply lines, which were very long and very vulnerable, secure. The war also showed the vulnerability of big ships despite whatever defences they might have in today's missile age.

Senator Hamer rightly drew attention to the fact that airborne early warning radar-to be able to do over the horizon targeting-is absolutely essential. He went on to make the case that shore-based airborne early warning is never any good at all. That position really has to be qualified. Airborne early warning aircraft, such as the E-2Cs, can be both shore-based and carrier-based, but a carrier very much bigger than the type of ship that is contemplated for the Australian Navy would be needed. To suggest that a helicopter airborne early warning system is an adequate system is to state the case only partly. It is better than nothing at all but it is not much use and it will probably be out- performed by any strike aircraft operating against it. There are major limitations with respect to range, time on station and the altitude to which helicopters can climb. This is quite apart from the mechanical unreliability and the associated problems they have. Unless a navy has an airborne early warning system it is in grave difficulties when operating on the surface with ships today against any attacking force.

Senator Hamer made the point that with fighter defence at sea there has to be a naval task force. I would agree with that, if the ships are there. The larger question is: Why are the ships there? Will Australia need ships in that position ? Given our responsibilities that is an arguable point. To provide both an AEW capacity and adequate fighter defence, one has to have a conventional carrier. These toys, such as the Invincible and the Iwo Jima class vessels, will not provide the resources that we need. They simply do not have the capability. Senator Hamer made a very valid point regarding the command and control function for the support of the fleet, but it is incorrect to assume that that function can be provided only by a carrier. It can be provided by any command ship. Senator Hamer then went on to discourse at length about the Harriers. I will say something about those in another speech at some other time. Basically, the Harrier was a proof of concept aircraft. I saw the first aircraft fly at Farnborough at the end of the 1950s. The Harrier set out to prove that an aircraft could take off and land vertically. It was never designed as a fighter or strike aircraft, but is has been put into those roles and it has some major and fundamental shortcomings in that area. Senator Hamer is incorrect when he suggests that missile defences are so successful that all air operations at sea will be conducted at low level and, therefore, a flying brick like the Harrier is able to fight on equal terms subsoncially with any strike aircraft coming in. That is not what it is about at all. The aim of the game is not to kill other aircraft; it is to kill other ships. With the stand-off strike capabilities of weapons such as the Harpoon and so on, one has to have target acquisition and pursuit; that is, a general capability to take on those aircraft at a point quite remote from the ships, which could well be done at altitude.

More than 20 Harriers were involved in the Falkland Islands dispute. On my count at least 42 were involved. Interestingly, while they had a successful kill rate against the Mirages far more Mirages or Argentinian aircraft were knocked out by surface-to-air missiles. Twenty-seven aircraft were credited to the Harriers and 40 aircraft to the surface-to-air missiles. Given the general poor state of the British surface-to-air missiles those figures tell us a lot. The success of the Harriers, as everyone concedes, came from the fact that they had the AIM-9L, the latest mark of the Sidewinder, which was a full hemisphere weapon. The Argentinians had nothing in any sense comparable with that.

I turn to a minor point. Senator Hamer talked about the way the Royal Air Force crews could land on the ships. He attributed that to the capability of the aircraft. As an old airman, I would rather take the point that it says a great deal for the training of the RAF crews that they could land on a ship at sea when they had never done it before. Without getting into details on this, the important thing was that the Harriers could not secure the area. The Argentinians were operating at will at night. It is a hell of an indictment for an aircraft which pretends to be a fighter not to be able to deny penetration of air space in all weather. The C130 transports of the Argentinian Air Force, which are the same as the Hercules in Australia, have a radar signature from their propellers and their huge bulk like a block of flats. If one cannot find a C130 at night one had better give up the business one is in. The Harriers never ever intercepted any of the C130s. Right up until the night before the fall of Port Stanley the C130s were going in there. Senator Hamer had something to say about the loss rate of the carriers. That is a rather specious argument. Since 1945 carriers have never operated in an opposed environment. They have been operating off-shore in places such as Korea and Vietnam, but they certainly were not subject to any counter operations.

I return to the point that the lesson of the Falkland Islands was basically the use of the blockade-the way the submarines blockaded the Argentinian fleet in the harbours. That is of great relevance to Australia, because anyone who invades this country will have to use sea-borne transport to get here in the end . With the submarines which we have we can mount a very effective blockade of our harbours. The second point was vulnerability of the large surface ships. In many ways the protagonists for a carrier of the HMS Invinvible type for Australia are in the same class as those generals in the First World War who failed to understand the importance of the machine gun and the way in which it would revolutionise technology on the battlefield. As a result a whole generation died. I hope we will not pay that price again.

My final argument on the Falklands is that as soon as they could the British moved in the Phantom aircraft. They make no secret of the fact that had they had the Phantoms, with the Hermes in its conventional role and not, as it was, converted to short deck vessel, they would not have suffered the losses they did . They would have been able to establish air superiority and protect their ships . The fact that as soon as they got the runway repaired they put in the Phantoms speaks volumes for the relevant performance of the two types of aircraft.

The final point I want to raise concerns the Department of Foreign Affairs estimate in relation to the administrative costs of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. This year the Bureau has been appropriated $8.4m for salaries and overtime. The appropriation is down roughly $1m on last year, but it is still $8.4m. The administrative costs for the Bureau amount to $1.3m, making a total of $9.7m. Australia has gone from operating one of the cheapest forms of foreign aid in the world, administratively, to getting the laurel wreath for operating one of the most expensive. That leads to the whole question of foreign aid, which runs in excess of $646.6m. These are difficult times and it is time to look critically at what a big block of money like that is doing. An amount of $646m would keep an awful lot of Australians in jobs if we expended it in the correct way.

There is the argument around that Australia has an obligation to give money to other countries in the form of overseas aid. As I understand the argument, it is completely immoral because people say that if we give a country $50m or $100m, we will buy its friendship. They do not ever take the argument beyond that point . I find that quite immoral. If we are doing something of value that enables a country to raise its standard of living, that is one thing; that is an argument. It is not an argument that necessarily takes priority over Australians' standard of living. We have to look far more critically at where a lot of our foreign aid is going and maybe review downwards the aid we give. If we were to put that $ 646m towards building roads or one of the developmental programs that this country needs, we would go a very long way towards reducing unemployment in this country and giving the stimulus to business that it needs to get going.

I am very concerned about the cost of government in Australia. It seems to become more expensive and more unanswerable year after year. It is exacting an enormous toll from the Australian business community. I do not believe we can go into the latter part of this decade and into the next decade with an ever- expanding government taking more and more from private business. There has to be a halt; there has to be an evaluation of what governments should be doing and how efficiently they go about their tasks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1 ) I want mainly to deal with the events in South Australia on Saturday last and the events that led up to them. Before I get on to that topic I want to make a few remarks about what Senator MacGibbon has said. I agree with his last remarks , that one of the ways we will overcome the unemployment problem in Australia is for a government to have enough courage to spend money on public works. Unfortunately the Government of which he is a member does just the opposite-it runs down the public works program and the public works employees. It has done this not only in the federal sphere but also to a very large extent in the State of South Australia. That is one of the reasons why the previous Premier, David Tonkin, after tomorrow morning will be officially the Leader of the Opposition.
—For a while.
—He will be the Leader of the Opposition for a long, long time.
—The party will give him the axe and put someone else in.

—No doubt the party will give him the axe but he will remain the Leader of the Opposition for the time that the people who sit behind him see fit to keep him there. Every time Senator MacGibbon speaks in this place he criticises the trade union movement. He blames the trade unionists for every ill that faces this country. That is completely wrong. The trade unionists are people to be looked up to. The trade union leaders are endeavouring only to get a just share of the cake for their members and to better their members' living standards. Every time honourable senators opposite make speeches about the terrible chaos this country is in, they have to blame the trade union movement. They ought to give credit to the trade unions.
—I have been a trade unionist.

—That makes it all the worse for Senator MacGibbon to criticise members of the trade union movement. One of his opening remarks was that he was opposed to compulsory unionism. I have never heard him complain in this Parliament about the compulsion which exists in his own dental profession. If a person had learned at university to be a dentist and wanted to put up his shingle in any town, would he be allowed by the dental organisation to do so? Of course he would not. He would not get supplies. Even the dental mechanics in most States are not allowed to fit dentures. They make the dentures to be fitted by the dentists. The dentists take the impressions in the front room and take them out to the back. The dental mechanic never sees the patient to whom the dentures are fitted. It is left to the person who extracts the teeth. If that is not compulsory unionism and a closed shop, what is? I hope that in my own State in the not too distant future dental mechanics will be registered. They will be able to make and fit dentures for people. They cannot do that at present as they can in Tasmania. A Labor government in Tasmania allowed the registration of dental mechanics. These people should be registered. The dentists themselves make the huge incomes, not the people who work in the back rooms manufacturing the dentures. Senator MacGibbon well knows that.

SPEECH.PARA: We can consider the situation of doctors. No doctor could go to any town in Australia and set himself up in a clinic or even in a one-man show because the other doctors would not allow him to use the facilities of the hospital. They would blackball him. This has happened on many occasions. Some years ago it happened in Whyalla. When a private doctor went there to consult, he was told immediately that he would not have available to him the facilities of the Whyalla hospital. We could go on to the chemists. If a chemist went to any town or suburb wanting to open up a chemist's shop, he would soon find himself in the position of not being able to get supplies because that profession is a closed shop. It is just the same as the union situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not. Stick to your union affairs.

—Of course it is. Senator MacGibbon has no argument against it. It happens. People in the profession have told me that. Every time Senator MacGibbon's Government gets the country into trouble, he blames the rank and file of the trade union movement. We never hear him talk about the captains of industry in the chambers of commerce--
—Order! the honourable senator will address the Chair.
—I am very pleased to do that, Mr Deputy President. I was trying to direct my remarks to the man who could not stand them. He has left the chamber. He knew that I was speaking the truth.
—Who was it who walked out?

—That was Senator MacGibbon. There is an old saying, 'If you cannot stand the heat in the kitchen, get out'. That is just what he has done. I have great pleasure in addressing you, Mr Deputy President, because I have high regard for you. As I was saying, we never hear honourable senators opposite or members of Tory governments complain about chambers of commerce and chambers of manufacture, because the members of those organisations are the people who fund such governments. No doubt that is why we find such hostility to a certain piece of legislation which has been introduced into this Parliament. I cannot talk about that legislation, although I do not think it is on the Notice Paper yet as it came before the Senate only today. There has been a back bench reaction because some members of the Government back bench do not want to see the people who support them having to pay up like pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, the people who pay their tax every week when they get their pay packets. There is no way they can evade tax but the captains of industry can. One of the reasons why industry is failing in this country is that it has become such a rort. That is one of the reasons why the Government has not got enough money to spend on capital works.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite may say that private enterprise is the backbone of the country but I think that is completely wrong. If governments do not provide the capital works program that should be provided-goodness knows, more capital works programs need to be carried out in this country today-there are no openings for private enterprise to manufacture the articles that governments require to carry out extensive public works. The sooner private enterprise wakes up to that fact the better.

The Government of South Australia in 1979, as soon as it was elected, set about running down the departments responsible for public buildings, highways, engineering and water supply. It did away with all the day labour and handed all the work over to private contractors. It has reached the stage now where the Bannon Labor Government will find itself in dire straits in trying to get the expertise to build up those departments again. Worse than that, the Bannon Labor Government will have to spend taxpayers' money on purchasing new machinery to bring the machinery capacity up to the stage it had reached when the Labor Government went out of office in South Australia in 1979. Much of the very good machinery we had at that time was sold at very low prices-I would say at peppercorn prices-to private contractors who have worn it out in their haste to make a quick buck. In the main it is the taxpayers of South Australia who have suffered. I am very pleased that because of the awareness of the electors in that State we now have a Labor Government. I am sure that in the next three years the Labor Government will do its very best to put South Australia back on the economic footing it deserves to be on and on which it was before the previous Labor Government was defeated in 1979.

I want to refer to a few remarks that I made in this place on 14 November 1979. I warned then that the Tonkin Government would have to deliver the goods or it would find itself back in Opposition. I am not a clairvoyant. There were some clairvoyants about leading up to the election. One bloke had to apologise in the Adelaide Advertiser either yesterday or today because he miscued. He was completely wrong when he forecast that the Tonkin Government would be returned to office. He was completely wrong. I have no faith in clairvoyants. I always deal with facts. Most of the statistics which I give in this place are compiled by recognised bodies. On 14 November 1979 I said that the Tonkin Government had been elected on untruthful election promises made not only by the Leader of the Opposition but also by the Chamber of Commerce and Industry and business people in that State. I said that they would live to rue the day. I referred to an advertisement that had appeared in the newspaper. I stated:
I refer to an advertisement that appeared in the Advertiser of 14 September-
That is, 14 September 1979-
together with a map of Australia. The advertisement reads:
'South Australia still has the highest unemployment rate in Australia'.
That's 8.2 per cent or 40,000 people out of work.

Of course, those figures were misleading to this extent: The unemployment figure had been overstated by 0.6 per cent. The true figure was 7.6 per cent. What is the figure in that State today? The latest figure which we have been given shows that the unemployment rate is nearly 9 per cent. About 55,000 people are out of work. Mr Tonkin was elected on a promise to stop the job rot. That promise was never honoured. As I have said in this chamber on repeated occasions, the only promise that Mr Tonkin ever honoured in the three years he was in office was to abolish death duties and gift duties. Of course, a lot of wage earners and working people voted for him not realising, of course, that under the previous Corcoran Government and Dunstan Government there was an exemption of $80,000 in respect of death duties. A husband and wife in joint ownership of a home could have assets to the value of $160,000. When one partner passed away the other would be exempt from paying death duty because they were in partnership. Who is paying for those promises that Mr Tonkin carried out? The pensioners, the unemployed and the people in the work force are paying because all State costs were put up by the Government to try to recover the $32m which was lost to revenue by the abolition of death duties and gift duties. We saw a massive escalation in the price of electricity, water and bus fares. Every avenue that was open to the State Government to raise money was exploited to try to recoup that money.

On top of that the State Government, under Mr Tonkin, sold off the State assets . South Australia had a very good land commission which was set up under the jurisdiction of Mr Dunstan in co-operation with the Whitlam Government. People were able to purchase land at reasonable prices. What did Mr Tonkin do? He got rid of the land commission. He handed land over to private developers. We had the Monarto commission which was established not many miles away from where I live. What happened to that? It was sold back to farmers. I am very disturbed when I go past that area now and see that all the magnificent trees planted during the reign of the Dunstan and Corcoran governments are dying through lack of attention. A very extensive reafforestation program was carried out in that area. Land has been sold back to farmers who, at the first opportunity, will again clear it. Trees on the area retained by the Government are not being looked after properly in my view. One can drive along the freeway and see trees dying in their hundreds. The trees ought to be watered in this time of drought to keep them alive. That is something else which happened under the Tonkin Government.

I could go right through, chapter and verse what I said on 14 November 1979 about what would happen under a Tonkin Government. What I said would happen has happened. One of the things that disturbed me was that on Tuesday, 13 November, nearly two months after the Tonkin Government was elected, a big supplement was published in the Advertiser. It was headed: 'South Australia. We hold it in our hands'. On 14 November 1979 I stated:
It was claimed to be presented by the commercial radio and television stations of South Australia in the interests of our State. The advertisement states:
We have a lot of things going for us. Yet nobody seems to take notice.
Chrysler and General Motors are here.
So, are Simpson, Pope, Kelvinator, Safcol, major universities, key hospitals, tradesmen and agriculture.
All working full blast.
The trees are blooming, the reservoirs are full and sales have never been better.
What this means is we can have confidence. Confidence in ourselves, our neighbours, our community and our State.
And its future.
So let's show it. And then stand back and watch South Australia grow.
South Australia. It's our State, mate.

Is it our State? What has happened? That advertisement was published in the daily Press about two months after Tonkin was elected. Of course, it implied that all those things happened after the election in September. Nothing of that kind occurred. All those things were in the pipeline. They were all operative under the Dunstan and Corcoran Labor governments. No credit was given to the Labor governments in those misleading advertisements leading up to the election. We found shortly after the election that advertisements appeared claiming all the credit for what was going on. I will refer later to a statement that was incorporated in Hansard by Senator Carrick during the last week the Parliament sat. He claimed that a whole list of industries had come to South Australia under the Tonkin Liberal Government. How misleading was that statement? I will refer to it later. On 14 November 1979 I went on to say:
The chickens are already coming home to roost. Those people have to live with their statements.
They are the people to whom I have referred. I continued:

As I said in this Parliament some days ago, the present Government in South Australia was elected on an untruth, and it has to live with it. It will have to answer to the electors at the first opportunity when it goes to the people. Along with my colleagues, I will be continually reminding the people.
Senator Missen interjected and said:
Is that a promise?
I replied:
That is a promise. I will continually remind the people of how they were misled by the false advertising put out by the people who are claiming that South Australia is a great State.

I could go on at some length about what I said on that day. I referred to another plank of the platform on which Mr Tonkin was elected-that he fully supported the policies of the Fraser Government. What has he been saying since Saturday night? He is blaming the Fraser Government for his defeat. He is not big enough or man enough to admit that his own policies brought the State to its knees and brought about his defeat. He is now turning around and blaming the Fraser Government for its policies. He is on record as saying that. I have read it in the paper, and I saw him on television on Saturday night very late. But there is the man who was elected saying that he fully supported the Fraser policies. Of course, the right thinking people in the electorate, when they got the opportunity last Saturday, reversed the decision of three years ago and they have now re-elected a Labor government.
In my final remarks in my speech on 14 November 1979 I said:
This is not the last time that I will be on my feet talking about these things in the remaining three years of the Tonkin Government.

In the last 12 months I have repeatedly given notices of motion pointing out just what has happened to the State of South Australia. In those notices of motion I have used figures and quotations from information which is provided to the community at large by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They have not been figures cooked up by the Labor Party. All those notices of motion are on the Notice Paper, and I shall have to do something tomorrow to have them removed because the people of South Australia have been alerted to what was going on and have made their decision, so it is no use leaving the notices of motion there to be debated because they are now out of date.

Let us look at what happened in this Parliament on 19 October. Senator Carrick was answering a question put to him by my colleague Senator Elstob about cost increases in South Australia. I have referred to some of those increases, but Senator Elstob had referred to the massive increase in hospital charges. He cited the increase in the price of a loaf of bread, and quite a few other things . During Senator Carrick's answer, Senator Walsh, referring to South Australia, said:
It has the highest unemployment on the mainland and 8,000 people a year are leaving the State.
Senator Carrick said in reply:
Again, honourable senators opposite do not like to hear the constructive things that are happening.
I interjected and said:
They don't like to hear distortions of fact. That is what we don't like.
And neither do we like them. Senator Carrick went on to talk about some of the things for which he claimed credit in South Australia. Referring to the Opposition, he said:
They do not like to hear of the vigorous actions of the South Australian Liberal Government in attracting industry.

The next day I put a question to Senator Carrick. I asked him just what industry had been attracted to South Australia during the reign of the Liberal Government . Whilst he went to great lengths to talk about the development of the Cooper Basin, I remind him that the Tonkin Liberal Government had nothing to do with the development of the Cooper Basin and that the Cooper Basin was developed under State Labor Governments, both the Dunstan Government and the Corcoran Government. I went on to ask Senator Carrick:

What are the names of the companies which have come to South Australia? What is the number of people employed at present in each of these industries? Finally, is it not a fact that even if the feasibility study being carried out at Roxby Downs gives the go-ahead, it will be at least nine years before jobs, in significant numbers, will be created?
That is what I posed to Senator Carrick. Then I asked this supplementary question about the companies that he said had come to South Australia:

I ask the Minister whether he could provide the names of the companies and he said that he would. Obviously, when he made the statement yesterday he must have known because, according to Hansard, he claimed that the South Australian Liberal Government had attracted industries. I now ask the Minister: Can I have that answer prior to 6 November so that we can ascertain whether, in fact these industries have been attracted to South Australia?
On 28 October Senator Carrick rose after Question Time-unfortunately I was not present, otherwise I might have sought leave to make a statement-and he said:

On 20 October Senator McLaren asked me a question without notice concerning industry development in South Australia. I undertook to seek out the names of companies that had come to South Australia during the term of office of the Tonkin Government

That is the answer that disturbs me, because many of the 84 companies that Senator Carrick listed were already in South Australia long before the Tonkin Government ever came to office. Here we had Senator Carrick standing in this place and incorporating in Hansard a list of 84 companies which he claims came to South Australia during the reign of the Tonkin Liberal Government. My colleague Senator Robert Ray interjected. He said:
The other interjection was: How many have left?

But Senator Carrick conveniently ignored that. Nothing has been put in this Hansard as to how many companies had left the State. Nor did Senator Carrick say , in answering my question, how many people were employed by the companies on that long list. In answer to Senator Ray's interjection, he went on to say:

I will pick up the interjection: 'How many have left?' The annual reports of the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission show that in 1979-80 and in 1980-81-that is two of the three years of the Tonkin Government-nearly 7000 new companies registered in South Australia.

It is all very well to register companies, but one can register a company that does not necessarily employ anyone. Senator Carrick did not go on to tell us that. He never told us, either, how many people were employed in those 7000 new companies. He listed 84 companies, thinking that he might get some kudos for Mr Tonkin. But he gave no answer as to how many people were employed by those companies. Concluding his answer, he said:

However, I have obtained from South Australia's Department of Trade and Industry a list comprising 84 major manufacturing projects, with total project costs amounting to more than $250m, which have been completed in South Australia since October 1979.
We all know that most of those industries were in South Australia prior to 1979 or were in the course of construction. But Senator Carrick was very emphatic in his remarks. He said:
I repeat, they represent projects that have been completed. Of course, they do not take into account the very substantial developments that are now taking place.
He went on to say:

Therefore, taken together, they more than confirm the evidence that the Tonkin Government has achieved the attracting of very substantial industry to South Australia. I repeat, the details cover only two of the three years involved.

Then Senator Carrick gave a list of the companies that he claims were attracted to South Australia by the Tonkin Government. The first on the list is Abbott Australasia Pty Ltd. That company has been in South Australia for a long time. I have never heard that it came there only recently and was attracted there by Mr Tonkin. The next is Adelaide Brighton Cement Ltd. That is mentioned twice, with an amount of money. But looking at the details, one finds that they are expansions to those companies. They are not companies that have been attracted there; they are expansions. Many of those expansions were in the pipeline long before Mr Tonkin ever got to the treasury bench. On the list also is Angliss, William & Co. at Wingfield, with the notation 'Establishment to manufacture tennis strings'. How much did that project attract to South Australia? It was $ 300,000. It did not employ many people, because we did not get the figures. Australian Bacon Ltd at Adelaide-Mount Barker is listed for an amenities block costing $200,000. That company has long been operating in South Australia. Berri Fruit Juices Co-op Ltd, at Berri, has long been operative in South Australia. Bridgestone Australia Pty Ltd, at Edwardstown, another expansion, has long been in South Australia.

There are six listings for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, three at Port Pirie and three at Whyalla. What has happened to those industries? Particularly at Whyalla, the work force is being retrenched at a rapid rate under the Tonkin Government. Of course, the shipbuilding industry was lost under the jurisdiction of the Fraser Government. When my colleague former Senator Bishop was in this place, he repeatedly reminded the Government of broken promises about keeping the shipyard open at Whyalla.

Next on the list is CSR Ltd at Glanville, and the upgrading of a sugar refinery , for $4m. That was an established industry many years ago. Then there is Charles David Pty Ltd, at Murray Bridge, and the upgrading of abattoirs. I live there. I can say categorically that that industry did not just come there in the last three years. It has been in South Australia for many years. Then we have listed Codan Pty Ltd, at Newton; Colan Shipbuilders Pty Ltd/Colan Engineers Pty Ltd, at Port Adelaide; The Commonwealth Industrial Gases Ltd; Crowhurst, W. P. Pty Ltd, at Devon Park, an expansion; Dairy Vale Metro Co-operative Ltd. at Jerbois. We come on to Faulding, and Freesia Ice Cream with the note 'relocation and expansion'. Freesia Ice Cream was an industry that was at Murray Bridge. The first job that I had when I went to Murray Bridge in 1950 was working as a builder's labourer mixing mortar to rebuild the factory which had been burnt down. It was owned by Smythe Brothers. It was burned down in about 1949. We have it listed here as some achievement of the Tonkin Liberal Government because it has transferred from Murray Bridge to Adelaide.

We then get Furness Ltd-'relocation and new factory'. We all know that Furness used to make very worthwhile and very good caravans in South Australia. It is not a new industry to South Australia. It is a long established industry. We then have listed General Motors-Holden's Ltd at Elizabeth. That company was there long before Mr Tonkin came to government. What is General Motors-Holden's doing now? It is retrenching employees in very large numbers. I can go on. He lists Messengers Press Pty Ltd, which is retrenching employees and closing down a lot of its throw-away papers; yet it is listed here as a great achievement. Mobil Oil Australia Ltd's lube oil refinery expansion operation is also listed. Mobil has been in South Australia for many years. I think it went there when the late Thomas Playford was Premier of the State. But that does not worry Senator Carrick in claiming it as an achievement for Mr Tonkin. The Onkaparinga Woollen Co. Ltd mill at Lobethal is retrenching workers. That company has been there for many years. We can look further to O.E. and D.R. Pope Pty Ltd at Kent Town. It is going to retrench workers this week. I also include the Port Lincoln Ship Construction Co. and the Port Lincoln Tuna Processors Pty Ltd, which has been catching tuna at Port Lincoln from as far back as I can remember, but it is claimed here as an achievement for the Tonkin Government. Sapfor Timber Mills Ltd at Tarpeena is the company which put off 75 workers recently and I complained about it in the Parliament, yet it is claimed as an achievement. B. Seppelt and Sons Ltd at Tanunda, John Shearer Ltd at Mile End and at Kilkenny, Simpson Ltd at Regency Park, Softwood Holdings Ltd at Mount Gambier-which is mentioned four times-the South Australian Brewing Co. Ltd, the South Australian Fishermen's Co-operative Ltd, the Southern Farmers Co-operative Ltd, Tubemakers of Australia Ltd at Kilburn-which has been mentioned twice-Joe White Maltings Ltd, Woods and Forests Department of Mount Gambier and W. H. Wylie and Co. Pty Ltd at Clovelly Park are all retrenching people.

How vigorous and viable was the Woods and Forests Department at Mount Gambier under the Dunstan and Corcoran governments when Mr Chatterton was the Minister of Forests? It was very viable, but there could be a problem down there now. It will not eventuate because a story was going around Mount Gambier last week that if Mr Tonkin had been re-elected there would have been severe retrenchments in the State mill. Fortunately that will not happen. All of these things can be listed. I have not listed the lot of them, which were tabled in this Parliament and incorporated in the Hansard by Senator Carrick in an effort to fool the people in South Australia as to what a great achiever Mr Tonkin was in attracting industry to South Australia.
