Well he got his answer on Saturday. I think the lesson is there for Senator Carrick. If he is going to fight the next Federal election on promises like that, trying to fool the people that the Liberal Goverment will attract industry and create employment, he has another think coming. We saw the happenings in Victoria earlier this year. The people are not fools all the time. As Abraham Lincoln said:
You can fool some of the people all of the time, and all of the people some of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time.

That is what happened in Victoria and in South Australia last Saturday. I join with my parliamentary colleagues on this side of the House in congratulating John Bannon on a magnificent victory. I say to the people who live in South Australia that they can look forward to good, stable and worthwhile government between now and the next election, whenever that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity, in speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83, to say a few words about the Budget. I believe the Budget is nothing more than an attempt by the Government to canvass votes for the next Federal election, whenever that will be. It is an addmission by this Government that the restrictive economic policies it has pursued over the last seven years have failed miserably. These policies have plunged Australia into the deepest recession since the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget comes at a time when unemployment is at record levels with already something like 500,000 Australians now officially listed as unemployed. It comes at a time when consumer confidence is at its lowest level for nine years and when the costs associated with buying a home are the highest on record. It comes at a time when dwelling approvals are at their lowest level for four years and when interest rates in Australia are among the highest in the world, and it comes at a time when our manufacturing industries are falling apart at the seams .

Not a single day goes past now without more companies announcing yet more retrenchments, and the jobs of thousands of Australian workers are now under threat. As recently as 15 September, another 2,500 workers were retrenched by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Newcastle and Port Kembla and a further 340 jobs at BHP's Whyalla plant in South Australia have already been lost or are being threatened. According to the Budget Papers, the Australian economy will not grow at all in 1982-83, making it the first time since the early 1960s that the economy has not grown. This Government has thrown economic planning out of the window, its policies are in disarray, and many of its Ministers have been shown to be totally incompetent. This Budget is a short term exercise in electioneering, just as we saw in 1977, when tax cuts were handed out just before the election and taken away not long after. The headlines on page one of the Australian Financial Review of 18 August said:
Fraser's seductive Budget is pitched at voters.

Quite clearly, it represents a complete reversal in economic strategy. Only last year Government Ministers in this chamber argued against any increase in the Budget deficit and now the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has brought down a Budget with a deficit of over $1,600m. As recently as February of this year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) went on record as saying that tax cuts will lead to more money floating around the economy and hence more inflation. Now he has brought down what would appear to be, on the surface, quite substantial income tax cuts. Of course, what we have not been told is how long these tax cuts are going to last. No guarantees have been made that they will not be taken away again, just as they were in 1977. I think the Canberra Times summed up the Budget quite effectively with the following words:
The Budget is the work of men with limited minds, obsessed by a false concept of responsibility, which they somehow inflicted upon far too many Australians.
The Sydney Morning Herald also launched an attack on the Budget and the motives behind it. It said:
From the Government's point of view the Budget offers only one hope: The hope of re-election, and that is just not good enough.
The Melbourne Age, in its editorial headed 'Budget for an Election', said quite rightly:

The Treasurer has admitted that it will do nothing to reduce inflation and that it cannot prevent an increase in unemployment. The strategy of seven years has failed; the hopes of an investment-led or consumer-led or resources-led recovery have faded; the boast of superior economic management has, by international comparisons been exposed as hollow.

So there we have it. Nearly every editorial in this country has labelled this Budget as a shallow piece of economic hogwash and seen it as a deliberate attempt to sway the middle ground swinging voters. As Bob Hawke said in the other place, and I must say I think he was quite generous, this truly is a ' Mickey Mouse Budget'. It is the sort of con trick one would expect to come from a government led by Idi Amin or the Ayotollah Khomeini.

I now want to look specifically at some of the contents of the Budget. In doing so, I want to say that I welcome the relief that has been given to many Australians, but overall I am afraid it is a case of too little, too late. Moreover, I share the concern of many people that the cuts may not be lasting, and that we may be in for a repeat of 1977-78 when income tax cuts were granted, only to be followed by an income tax surcharge less than 12 months afterwards.

One point in particular I make in relation to the income tax cuts is that all of the tax relief measures announced in the Budget did not come into effect until November. In the meantime, indirect taxes, such as the sales taxes and the excise on beer and cigarettes annouced in the Budget, came into effect immediately after the Budget. This is clearly a ridiculous situation. If these measures were going to be as important in contributing to a consumer-led recovery as the Treasurer claims, they should have been backdated to July or at least to the day of the Budget. That would have given people more substantial relief and provided a much needed boost to retail sales.

On the housing front, while mortgage repayments on the average home loan have gone up by something like $25 a week over the last 2 1/2 years, the average amount of assistance provided by means of the home loan interest rebate will be between $5.05 a week and $8.65 a week. This is a long way short of the increase in repayments brought about by rising interest rates. One section of the community which will be hardest hit by this Budget are those on fixed incomes- the pensioners and the unemployed. The standard pension rate currently represents 21.9 per cent of average weekly earnings, considerably less than the 24.5 per cent it represented in 1975. The Budget brings only superficial relief in that the tax threshold has been lifted from $4,195 to $4,595, together with a rebate of $250. However, this applied only from November, which means that the maximum rebate will be only $167, with pensioners still paying tax if they earn over $5,007. This means that a large number of the 300,000 pensioners and low income earners the Treasurer stated will not be paying tax this year will, in fact, end up doing so anyway.

Another inadequate provision is the supplementary rent assistance given to pensioners renting private accommodation. This has been increased by a miserable $2 a week at a time when rents have gone up something like $10 to $15 a week. Also, there is still no such supplementary assistance paid to the unemployed, just as the unemployed have still not been granted the same sorts of fringe benefits which apply to pensioners. In fact, this Government has shown such callous disregard for the unemployed, that the rate of unemployment benefit paid to persons without dependants is still $12.85 below the single pension rate. Even worse is the miserable increase of only $4 a week granted to young unemployed people aged 16 and 17. How they are expected to live on the paltry sum of $40 a week is beyond me. It is about time the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) came to grips with the sorts of problems being faced by Australia's homeless young people.

Even one of the Government's own senators has recognised the inadequacy of the present level of benefit paid to young unemployed people. When Senator Walters was commenting on the report on homeless youth by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, she said:

It would seem that the present philosophy of the Government with regard to the junior unemployment rate of, as it was, $36 is that it is only meant to support those 16 and 17-year-olds living in the parental home. The economic and social factors on which the junior rate was set six years ago have altered significantly and it is therefore important that the Government make clear the basis on which the junior rate is determined and that that rate is expected to cover. Not only would it be impossible for anyone to live independently on $36 a week, but in the case of a number of other unemployed youth, that amount of money would not be sufficient to support them in the family home, particularly if the parents are unemployed or are in receipt of a pension. While I am encouraged by the recent Budget announcement to lift this rate by 11 per cent, to $40 as from November 1982, it still does not lessen the concerns I have just raised.

The Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, must use his influence in Cabinet to bring about a more equitable situation. The fact is, one simply cannot force all 16 or 17-year-olds to stay at home with their parents until they reach the age of 18, no matter what one may think is right personally. In refusing to raise the level of benefits for 16 and 17-year-olds above $40 a week , the Government has no doubt forced many of these young people into prostitution and exposed them to drug traffickers and other underworld characters. The $4 increase in the amount of unemployment benefit paid to 16 and 17-year-olds is the first increase for seven years and represents a massive decrease in the real value of that benefit of 50 per cent over the life of this Government. Just to remain at 1975-76 levels in real terms, the benefit would have to have been increased to something like $65 to $70 a week. The maximum rate payable to 16 and 17-year-olds has fallen from 24.5 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1975 to just 11 per cent in the June quarter of 1982.

Another deficiency of the Budget is the failure to increase the amount available for emergency relief at a time when voluntary organisations are being pushed to the brink with people in urgent need of food and shelter. The indirect tax increases, such as the increases in sales taxes across the board and the increase in the beer and tobacco excise, will certainly hurt the pensioners, the unemployed and everybody else in the community who depends on fixed incomes.

I turn briefly to the new fuel tax to be introduced as part of the so-called Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. This new tax on motorists is apparently designed to contribute $150m to the construction of our national road system. But the fact of the matter is that it is merely a ploy to raise more revenue, to make up for the decrease in real allocations to the States, under the Roads Grants Act, in 1982-83. This Government has deliberately ignored our road system for the past seven years, and as a result, we have one of the worst road systems in the developed world. Small two-lane country roads covered with potholes are meant to take us between our major cities. The Government's failure to remedy this has no doubt contributed to the high number of fatalities on our country roads. Our national highway system is an absolute shambles. The amounts to be spent in 1982-83 will certainly not go far enough to alleviate the problem .

I now want to speak about what I consider to be the most serious deficiency in the 1982-83 Budget. It concerns the inability of this Budget to provide any solution to the growing unemployment problem in this country. In fact, the Government has finally admitted that it is completely and utterly helpless. This was summed up very well by Ken Davidson in the Age on 18 August 1982 when he said:

It's now official. The Government has abandoned the full employment objective which has hitherto been the stated objective of all parties and governments since the Chifley Government published its White Paper on full employment in 1945.

This Budget contains absolutely nothing for the unemployed. It leaves them in complete despair and with no hope for the future. The Treasurer has admitted that unemployment will rise to 8 per cent in this financial year.

The Flinders University Institute of Labour Studies has predicted that the number of unemployed people will increase to at least 700,000 in 1982-83, an average of some 75 per cent over 1981-82. This will represent an increase in unemployment over the last two years of nearly 100 per cent. Yet, while all this has been happening, staffing levels in the Commonwealth Employment Service have been falling. In 1981-82 there was an 8 per cent reduction in CES staff at a time when unemployment increased by 26 per cent. In 1982-83, according to the Budget estimates, staffing levels will increase by only one per cent. We have seen a 7 per cent effective reduction in CES staff over the last two years. This is a measure of this Government's concern for the unemployed.

We can spend all the money in the world on training schemes but they do not create real jobs. In my home state of South Australia the situation is particularly bad in the outer suburban areas, with the unemployment rate in the Elizabeth and Munno Para areas north of Adelaide estimated to be about 32 per cent of the work force, that is, one in every three people. Similarly, in Whyalla, the unemployment rate is estimated to be about 31 per cent, according to Department of Social Security figures, and in the Morphett Vale-Noarlunga areas it is about 26 per cent. Youth unemployment in South Australia is now hovering around 30 per cent.

Since the beginning of the year we have seen General Motors-Holden's Ltd retrench 220 workers. One hundred workers have lost their jobs at the Mount Barker tannery, 105 were retrenched by Alco Industries (Aust.) Pty Ltd at Elizabeth, 125 by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Whyalla, 50 by the Kenwood organisation, 420 by Kelvinator Australia Ltd, with more to come, 95 by Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, 75 by Sapfor Timber Mills Ltd and so the list goes on. This Budget will do absolutely nothing to stop this disastrous trend. It will do nothing to aid manufacturing industries. It certainly does nothing to assist small business people in the community. The sales tax increases on cars and white goods will only add to the plight of these industries in the next 12 months. The industries are vital to South Australia and in the face of intense competition from imports and dumped products from Asia, especially in the white goods area, these sales tax increases can lead only to more unemployment in these industries over the next 12 months.

This Budget is a culmination of seven years of the most incompetent and corrupt government that Australia has seen. The Government has ripped off the ordinary Australian people for the last seven years, with the proportion of the tax burden borne by the pay-as-you-earn wage and salary earners rising from 41.7 per cent in 1975-76 to around 45.4 per cent in 1982-83. Australia has one of the highest rates of income tax among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The changes to the tax scales included in this Budget are a deliberate attempt by this Government to pull the wool over people's eyes. While it has granted some miserable tax cuts to wage and salary earners, the wealthiest 10 per cent of the population are still getting away with thousands of millions of dollars in unpaid tax. As the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union showed, since 1975, whilst the actual number of companies has increased or remained constant, the number of companies paying tax has fallen by around 20, 000. In 1982-83 the amount of tax paid by companies will actually fall by one per cent, which represents an 11 per cent or 12 per cent reduction in real terms . Meanwhile, the average taxpayer is now paying 83 per cent more in tax than he was when the Fraser Government came to power.
This Budget is summed up very well in an article by Brian Toohey in the National Times in which he states:
The pervasive mood underlying last Tuesday's Budget is one of helplessness. The economy is careering towards the cliff edge and the Government has taken its hand off the wheel.

All that this Government has in the way of a so-called economic strategy is wage moderation. In other words, what it is advocating is that to solve our problems the ordinary working men and women of this country have to accept a drop in living standards. What an admission of failure. As Brian Toohey said in the National Times:
. . . If low wages were an unqualified good, Bangladesh should be a shining example of economic wisdom.
I think this speaks for itself. As the editorial in the conservative Australian Financial Review said, in commenting on the Budget:

It has left Australia without a wage policy, indeed without an economic policy. It has guaranteed that the social and economic costs of the recession will not be shared equitably, but will be concentrated on the unemployed.

I, for one, do not think that the Australian people will be conned by this Budget. I think they will see it for what it really is, a cheap and nasty attempt to win votes for the election, whenever it is. I condemn this Budget for its total failure to come to grips with Australia's economic problems and for its failure to provide an economic strategy to revive the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) to draw attention to the crisis in the provision of basic shelter. Today Australia has the highest real interest rates for housing since the Second World War. The statement by my colleague Senator McLaren this afternoon, drawing attention to the fact that one of the largest private banks is now taking the first steps to foreclose on people who are unemployed, is indicative of the problems that many Australians face because of high interest rates and the general failure of the Fraser Government's housing policies. At the same time, thousands of Australians are living in sub-standard or over priced accommodation. A recent report from Philippa Smith of the New South Wales Council of Social Service showed that people on low incomes are paying phenomenal percentages of those incomes in rent. In many cases people on low incomes or people receiving social services benefits are paying half the money they receive in rent. Indeed, some of these people are paying all their money on shelter. They are eating into their accumulated resources of a lifetime because they cannot get adequate shelter at reasonable cost.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a housing policy crisis. The Fraser Government's attitude when facing this crisis has been to get rid of the Department of Housing and Construction, to prevent the overall view being in the hands of one department, to fragment the former ministry and give responsibilities for housing to the Department of Social Security, the Department of Transport and Construction and other government departments. I think that sums up the cynicism with which the Fraser Government has tackled the housing problem. Of course, we also have to consider the fact that the complete burden of housing has been thrown onto the States. In addition to the States, the most obvious recipients of the ball thrown away by the Fraser Government, local government is increasingly facing problems because of the shelter crisis.

Funds for public housing have been slashed by two-thirds since 1974. That is the level of crisis that I am describing. Since the last full year of a Labor government the actual money available has been slashed by two-thirds. This represents in public houses 75,000 dwellings that could have been built. In other words, we do not have those 75,000 dwellings because of the slow and deliberate policy of the Fraser Government to reduce our housing stock. I will contrast this chaos at the Federal level with some of the innovations that are taking place in local government. But I think we have to look for new solutions at the national level to meet what, after unemployment, is the greatest social problem that this nation faces. With regard to housing as a social good, I think the Government has given lip service to housing but I feel that we have to go further than the Government is prepared to go. Special consideration must be given to the economic cost of housing and the economic benefit of a flourishing housing industry.

I believe that housing investment need not hinder the economic growth of our country; quite the reverse, I believe that we should use money on housing to aid recovery and to aid growth at this moment when unemployment is reaching unparalleled proportions, even with the acknowledged background of the Fraser Government. We have a tremendous crisis in unemployment to which my colleague Senator Foreman has referred. The fact is that we have to use housing in trying to resolve that problem. I am indebted to Hugh Stretton who indicated, in a paper entitled 'Housing-An Investment For All', a number of positive aspects of the housing industry that I commend to honourable senators. For example, he has pointed out that between one-third and one quarter of material goods and services are produced in households. That is a novel thought because it involves the issue that housework and a number of other activities do take place in the household. He stated:

Somewhere between a third and 45 per cent of our material goods and services are produced in households, or by other unpaid labour in other co-operative organizations. That output is likely to go on increasing in volume and importance. Whether or not we're in for substantial technological unemployment, we certainly face shorter hours of paid work, longer education and longer retirement, and altogether more leisure. The capital resources of household and neighbourhood and voluntary association seem likely to be more important than ever.
He continued:
So we need appropriate allocation of capital between households and other productive users.

I think that is a novel thought but it is a realistic appreciation of the fact that more and more is going to occur in the areas that he has described and so there is even more need for us to have a progressive and vital housing industry. Hugh Stretton went on to refer to the attributes of the building industry. He said:
The house-building industry can be a stable, long-term-reliable one, while at the same time running with extreme competitive efficiency.

We all know that the efficiency of the industry is based on the fact that we have everything in the building industry from a one person organisation to large construction companies. The advantage of the housing industry is that it is also an industry that allows for development in that it has an employment multiplier of one to one. For every person employed directly in the housing and construction industry there is one person employed in the consequential industries which back it up. In the paper that I have referred to, Hugh Stretton made the point that it is an industry that is protected naturally. It needs no tariffs. I thought that might appeal to some Government senators who are obsessed with the protection of industry. The import component in the housing industry is a very modest one. If it was necessary even to reduce some of the luxury items that go into the housing industry-or perhaps the top end of the housing industry for the people who are closely aligned with the Liberal and National parties-then we could reduce still further the import section of the housing industry simply by taking some action to prevent the luxury end of the industry from being flooded with material from overseas that is not necessary for the 80 or 90 per cent of Australian people who want modest but reasonable shelter.

The other factor that I think is common knowledge to everybody, but is worth restating, is that the building industry can provide employment for people whether they be unskilled, semi-skilled or skilled. To this extent, in looking at an economic recovery, as we are in the Labor Party, the use of that work force in the housing industry, one that can quickly be put to work, would be something that we regard as very desirable. It would quickly reduce the battalions of unemployed people who have been conscripted into this Government's so-called campaign against inflation, the unfortunate people who are suffering at present throughout this country. The housing industry would give us all these attributes and yet the very appropriations that we face today indicate that the Government has done so very little for it.

One of the things that Hugh Stretton emphasised in his paper is the fact that there seems to be some correlation between some of the countries that have been credited with economic miracles-Sweden, West Germany, Holland, Japan, Hong Kong and Singapore. He points out that one of the common factors in the economic success of all of those diverse countries is that they have taken action to support their housing and construction industries. He said that if we look at the celebrated economic miracles of those years in which these countries expended great moneys in their housing industries, it does not take long to see as he puts it, that:

Those countries directed to housing construction about twice the resouces that market forces alone would have done, and while doing that, and partly by doing that, they led the world in economic growth.

Thus a viable and vibrant housing industry, which certainly requires the input of more effort than market forces alone can produce, is able to produce of itself a satisfactory rate of growth. That subject was taken up by another world famous economist, Barbara Ward, in her book The Home of Man. Commenting on the German experience, she said:

. . . the Germans have proved that if a resourceful and hard-working people devote a steady five or six per cent of their gross national product to housing a vast transformaton can be achieved in only two decades. Nor can anyone, following the growth of the German economy through the same period, argue that the priority for housing has acted as much of a drag on other sectors. On the contrary, the very steadiness and comprehensiveness of the program has been an important stimulus to the rest of the economy . . . If wealthy industrialized countries want to give their citizens decent homes, they can.
Thus we have evidence from other countries that the expenditure of money in the general provision of shelter for our people can produce general economic gain for the community as a whole.

I would like briefly to contrast the initiative taken by this Government with that shown by one of the smallest municipal councils in the city of Sydney. I refer to the Waverley Council, whose activities cover some of the most attractive parts of Sydney, including Bondi Beach and a number of other eastern suburbs beaches. The municipality lies close to my home and I know that the Council has taken steps to combat the special problems that it faces. Bondi and neighbouring areas of Sydney attract many unemployed young people. They crowd into flats, so that many live in unsatisfactory conditions. That lack of accommodation is the direct result of inadequate financing for the provision of homes and shelter. The Waverley Council has taken action to endeavour to maximise the accommodation available, but in so doing it has not been dogmatic. It has made sure that its activities have been combined with those of the local community, including the house building industry and the housing industry generally. In addition it set out in April 1980 to appoint a community housing officer. That was done with the complete support of the State Labor Government. An attempt has been made to evaluate how such an officer can assist a council that is burdened because of the magnet Bondi Beach represents for so many young people.

The aim of the Council, the aldermen, the community housing officer and other officials has been to create an integrated policy framework and, most particularly, to adopt an interventionist approach in order to try to house the people who come to its area. In that regard the Council has been very successful . By research and analysis it has sought to monitor the capacity of the local area to provide housing. It has looked at its own stock and has set out to provide housing by way of flats and other low income shelter. By engaging in joint ventures with developers it has tried to increase housing availability. In addition, group approaches have been made to charitable and other organisations in the area with a view to looking after those who have special problems. I refer to the aged, the mildly intellectually handicapped and homeless youth. At all times the Council has encouraged self-management in regard to housing issues , especially in 'share a home', an innovative approach for young people. This has been in addition to its work on the single women's refuge program. If the results of the intervention by Waverley Council, in particular its promotion of interaction between local, State and national housing interests, are viewed as beneficial, it is most important that we in the national Parliament consider more seriously the direction that housing is to take in this country.

As I said at the outset, the answer of this Government has been to reduce dramatically the amount of housing finance that it makes available. It has abolished its housing and construction ministry. It has thrown to a number of other departments, in a piecemeal way, the responsibility for providing housing. In the eyes of the Australian people, the actions of the Government in regard to this second most important issue, after unemployment, especially in view of the combined problems of unemployment and lack of shelter that people face today, are such that it stands condemned and must be judged as an abject failure in combating the lack of housing that exists at present.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

In particular, I refer to what I regard as inadequate answers by Mr Green, the Chief Reporter of the Commonwealth Reporting Service in Canberra, to questions asked by Estimates Committee A on 13 September 1982. What has been represented by the Commonwealth Reporting Service management as a rationalisation of operations is simply, in my view, bad management. Discussions of the Melbourne Commonwealth Reporting Service personnel with senior Commonwealth Reporting Service officers suggested the possibility of the Melbourne and Sydney offices of that body being reorientated as recording centres. That would be away from extensive transcript preparation. This proposal was raised over two years ago, but at no time were the current Melbourne staff informed of the management's intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: Although it may be denied officially, Melbourne typists were told on 26 August that significant areas of Melbourne generated work would be exclusively sent interstate in future. These areas include all Family Court of Australia work, Federal bankruptcy, Administrative Appeals Tribunal and Australian Taxation Office work. Mr Green is alleged to have said that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission work could also be sent interstate. It is true that additional casual staff have been employed in Adelaide to cover the Melbourne work load. The percentage of transcription work transferred from Melbourne over the last 12 months was not 30 per cent, as stated by Mr Green, but rather a 60: 40 ratio for the period 1 July 1981 to 30 June 1982. Since then the position has got worse. If, and only if, existing Melbourne facilities and personnel were unable to cope with the work load there might be some rational reason for transferring work interstate. Even then, the fact that work originates in Melbourne would be a powerful argument, I believe, for expanding the Melbourne office of the Commonwealth Reporting Service.

In relation to the fact that existing facilities in Melbourne are underutilised at the moment-no justification for this has been put forward-in my view, it was completely misleading for Mr Green to say that the work in Melbourne is queuing up or left to lie in one place for a week. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In February 1981 was the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) to begin producing a one-hour variety series involving the English entertainer Mike Batt; if so, was Mr Batt flown to Australia from Britain to star in the series.
(2) Was Mr Batt and the entire cast and production crew assembled for the series when it was abruptly cancelled.
(3) Was this cancellation due to the fact that the ABC had failed to seek permission from Actors' Equity for an overseas entertainer to perform here.
(4) How much did this cancellation cost the ABC directly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Mr Batt arrived mid-December, 1981 on board his motor vessel. He did not fly to Australia.

(2) No. Rehearsal with cast commenced 20 February. Vision taping was due to commence 26 February 1982. The completion of the television program was delayed pending an agreement being reached between Actors' Equity and the ABC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has there been a 25 per cent reduction in the staff ceiling on the research section within the National Acoustic Laboratories.

(2) Was this decision made prior to the Australian Science and Technology ( ASTEC) report being made public and prior to the Independent Committee of Enquiry into Commonwealth laboratory services and facilities even beginning its deliberations.
(3) Does the Applied Noise Research Section of NAL provide a consultancy service on noise problems to government departments and instrumentalities.
(4) Have all departments been made aware of the cessation of this service; if so, have they been given adequate time to make alternative arrangements.
(5) Are all departments also aware of the costs involved in engaging private acoustical consultants.
(6) Has provision been made in the Department of Health estimates for cost of consultants' services in relation to facilities in NAL Hearing Centres.
(7) Was a cost benefit analysis carried out in relation to these services prior to making the decision to abolish the Applied Noise Research Section.
(8) Has any thought been given to the need for expertise and staff to be available to evaluate the work done by outside consultants.
(9) Have progressive staff cuts already meant delays in the testing of hearing protectors.
(10) Does the Applied Noise Research Section publish a report used by health groups, industry and public.
(11) Are steps being taken to ensure this program is continued; if not, is it realised that the cost of testing individual hearing protectors by private industry will be $2,000-$5,000.
(12) Will this have a significant effect on the price of these hearing protectors.

(13) Since private consultants will now have to be engaged for acoustic services (i.e. performance specification checking of audiometric booths, design and planning of new facilities, etc.) in NAL Hearing Centres, will this cause further delays in provision of hearing services to the public.
(14) Will it affect the quality of the service.
(15) What expertise will be available to evaluate the work done by consultants on acoustic engineering matters such as mentioned above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. In giving effect to its 1981-82 staff ceiling my Department found it necessary to reduce the staffing of the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) by 6. Because of the need to give priority to those areas of NAL involved in the provision of hearing aids to eligible members of the public, it was decided to discontinue certain work undertaken for other Government Departments by the Applied Noise Research Group, and to reduce its staffing accordingly.

(2) Yes. The reduction in staff ceiling applied to NAL was determined before the ASTEC Report was made public and prior to the independent enquiry mentioned because these were not considered relevant to the decision. The report of the enquiry is still to be released. It was necessary for my Department to reduce to its approved 1981-82 staff ceiling as quickly as possible and staffing priorities had to be implemented promptly. To have awaited these reports would have impeded my Department's achieving its approved overall staffing level within the requested time.
(3) Yes, the Applied Noise Research group has, when requested, provided a consultancy service to other Government Departments and instrumentalities.

(4) Those Departments (formerly Defence, Transport and Housing and Construction ) who were regular users of the consultancy service on noise problems have been given adequate notice of the cessation of activities.
(5) Commonwealth Departments wishing to engage private acoustical consultants would be aware of the related costs.
(6) No consultant services are expected to be required by my Department as a result of these changes. Therefore, no provision has been made in funds estimates.

(7) No. Staffing reductions had to be implemented to enable my Department to meet its staff ceiling. A cut in this area was considered to have the least adverse impact on the services provided by NAL to eligible members of the public . In the circumstances, a formal cost benefit analysis was not considered appropriate.

(8) Consultants chosen by the Departments would be expected to be of such a calibre that their technical advice would be reliable. Senior officers of the Department concerned would assess the appropriate action on any recommendations made.
(9) Because of other work priorities there have been some delays within NAL in the testing of ear protectors.
(10) A report called 'Attenuation of Hearing Protectors' is published by the National Acoustic Laboratories.
(11) Necessary work in this area of hearing protectors will be continued.

(13) It is not intended that private consultants be engaged for acoustic services relating to performance specification checking or audiometric booths, design and planning of new facilities in NAL Hearing Centres.
